THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
The State,       
Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Michael Gonzales,       
Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Spartanburg County
Gary E. Clary, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No.Â  3842
Heard May 13, 2004 â€“ Filed July 6, 2004

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
TaraÂ  Shurling, of Columbia, for Appellant.
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney 
  General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Charles H. Richardson, 
  Assistant Attorney General David A. Spencer, all of Columbia; and Solicitor 
  Harold W. Gowdy, III, of Spartanburg, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM: Michael Gonzales was convicted 
  of trafficking in methamphetamine pursuant to section 44-53-375 of the South 
  Carolina Code and sentenced to thirty years imprisonment and a $200,000 fine.Â  
  He appeals, arguing the trial court (1) lacked subject matter jurisdiction to 
  impose judgment due to a faulty indictment, and (2) erred in admitting improper 
  character evidence at trial.Â  We affirm.
FACTS
Gonzales was arrested after selling one 
  pound of methamphetamine to undercover agents of the Spartanburg County Sheriffâ€™s 
  Department. Â This transaction was the culmination of an investigation 
  that began earlier the same day when Johnny Solomon offered to work as an informant 
  for the sheriffâ€™s office.Â  
On June 3, 2002, Solomon contacted 
  Officer Rhett Fox and informed him that he had the ability to purchase marijuana 
  from Gonzales.Â  At the behest of Fox, Solomon placed a recorded phone call to 
  Gonzales from Foxâ€™s office.Â Â  Gonzales informed Solomon that he could not sell 
  any marijuana, but could sell him one pound of the â€œother stuffâ€ for â€œthirteen 
  five.â€Â  Solomon testified he understood â€œother stuffâ€ to mean methamphetamine 
  and â€œthirteen fiveâ€ to mean a sale price of $13,500.Â  Gonzales and Solomon arranged 
  to meet later that afternoon in the bathroom of a local convenience store to 
  complete the transaction.Â  After three additional recorded conversations between 
  Gonzales and Solomon concerning the sale, a meeting time of approximately 5:50 
  p.m. was agreed upon.
An undercover officer posing as 
  the interested buyer accompanied Solomon, who was fitted with a body wire to 
  record the transaction.Â  Â Fox and other officers monitored the wire transmissions 
  from a truck parked on the edge of the convenience store parking lot.Â  Â The 
  officers were waiting for the audio â€œtake-down signalâ€ before moving in to make 
  an arrest. 
Gonzales arrived at the convenience 
  store with co-defendant Steven Shelhamer.Â  Gonzales and Solomon entered the 
  store and had a brief conversation, during which Solomon, as instructed, informed 
  Gonzales that the transaction was to occur outside.Â  Gonzales left the store 
  and moved his vehicle next to that of the undercover officer.Â  After he was 
  introduced to Gonzales, the officer asked where the drugs were located.Â  Gonzales 
  answered that they were in Shelhamerâ€™s possession.Â Â  Shelhamer handed a package 
  wrapped in black plastic and tape to the officer.Â Â  While weighing the package, 
  the officer gave the takedown signal, and the other officers moved in to make 
  the arrest.Â Â  Gonzales fled the scene on foot, but was later arrested.
The package handed to the undercover officer 
  contained 448.8 grams of methamphetamine surrounded by a layer of mustard and 
  a layer of barbeque sauce, [1]  
  all separated by plastic and wrapped in electrical tape. Â Â Gonzales was 
  indicted for trafficking in methamphetamine pursuant to section 44-53-375 of 
  the South Carolina Code and tried jointly with codefendant Shelhamer.Â  See 
  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 44-53-375 (2002).Â  Appellant was convicted and sentenced to 
  thirty years imprisonment and fined $200,000.Â  This appeal follows.
LAW / ANALYSIS
I.Â  Subject Matter Jurisdiction
Gonzales contends that his indictment 
  for â€œtrafficking in methamphetamine . . . in violation of Â§44-53-375,â€ was insufficient 
  to convey subject matter jurisdiction to the trial court because section 44-53-375 
  does not contain the specific word â€œmethamphetamine.â€Â Â  We disagree.
For a circuit court to have subject matter jurisdiction 
  to convict a defendant of an offense, one of three things must occur: (1) the 
  grand jury true bills an indictment which sufficiently states the offense; (2) 
  the defendant waives presentment in writing; or (3) the offense is a lesser 
  included offense of a crime adequately charged in a true billed indictment.Â  
  State v. Primus, 349 S.C. 576, 579, 564 S.E.2d 103, 105 (2002); see 
  also Carter v. State, 329 S.C. 355, 362, 495 S.E.2d 773, 777 (1998); 
  Browning v. State, 320 S.C. 366, 368, 465 S.E.2d 358, 359 (1995).Â  An 
  indictment adequately conveys subject matter jurisdiction to a trial court only 
  if it states the charged offense â€œwith sufficient certainty and particularity 
  to enable the court to know what judgment to pronounce, and the defendant to 
  know what he is called upon to answer.â€Â  Carter, 329 S.C. at 362, 495 
  S.E.2d at 777.Â  In determining whether an indictment meets this standard, however, 
  a court should look at the indictment with a practical eye in view of all the 
  surrounding evidence.Â  State v. Gunn, 313 S.C. 124, 130, 437 S.E.2d 75, 
  78 (1993). 
Gonzales was indicted for â€œTrafficking in Methamphetamine 
  . . . in violation of Â§44-53-375, The Code of Laws of South Carolina, (1976), 
  as amended.â€Â  Â Section 44-53-375(C) reads as follows:

A person who knowingly sells, manufactures, delivers, purchases, 
  or brings into this State, or who provides financial assistance or otherwise 
  aids, abets, attempts, or conspires to sell, manufacture, deliver, purchase, 
  or bring into this State, or who is knowingly in actual or constructive possession 
  or who knowingly attempts to become in actual or constructive possession of 
  ten grams or more of ice, crank, or crack cocaine, as defined and otherwise 
  limited in Sections 44-53-110 . . . is guilty of a felony which is known 
  as â€œtrafficking in ice, crank, or crack cocaineâ€. . . .

(Emphasis added.)Â  Section 44-53-110 (2002), the 
  definitional section of chapter 53 specifically referenced in the â€œtrafficking 
  in ice, crank, or crack cocaineâ€ statute, defines â€œiceâ€ and â€œcrankâ€ as â€œamphetamine 
  or methamphetamine.â€Â  
While the statute referenced in Gonzalesâ€™s 
  indictment does not include the specific term â€œmethamphetamineâ€ in its text, 
  it does list the termâ€™s commonly accepted synonyms of â€œcrankâ€ and â€œice.â€ Furthermore, 
  it clearly guides the defendant to the definitional statute where â€œcrankâ€ and 
  â€œiceâ€ are defined as â€œmethamphetamine.â€Â  Previously, this court has stated that 
  â€œ[a]n indictment phrased substantially in the language of the statute which 
  creates and defines the offense is ordinarily sufficient.â€Â  State v. Guthrie, 
  352 S.C. 103, 108, 572 S.E.2d 309, 312 (Ct. App. 2002); see also 
  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 17-19-20 (Supp. 2003); State v. Shoemaker, 276 S.C. 
  86, 88, 275 S.E.2d 878, 879 (1981).Â  Here, with the exception of this transposition 
  of synonyms, the indictment is phrased in almost the exact language of the statute.Â  

In State v. Owens, 346 S.C. 637, 
  552 S.E.2d 745 (2001), the supreme court held an indictment, even one that fails 
  to allege a key element of an offense, sufficiently vests the circuit court 
  with subject matter jurisdiction when a statute outlining the elements of the 
  offense is referenced in the body of the indictment.Â  Owens, 346 S.C. 
  at 649, 552 S.E.2d at 751-52.Â  In the case at bar, the indictment referenced 
  such a statute, which in turn, clarified the elements of the offense by its 
  own reference to a separate definitional statute.Â  The fact that the statute 
  referenced by Gonzalesâ€™s indictment referenced another statute for definitional 
  clarification does not constitute a substantial factual departure from the holding 
  of Owens.
When viewing the sufficiency of an indictment 
  from a practical standpoint, our fundamental determination â€œis not whether it 
  could be made more definite and certain, but whether it contains the necessary 
  elements of the offense intended to be charged and sufficiently apprises the 
  defendant of what he must be prepared to meet.â€ Guthrie, 352 S.C. at 
  108, 572 S.E.2d at 312.Â  In the case before us, a specific listing of the alternative 
  terms for methamphetamine (i.e. â€œice,â€ â€œcrankâ€) in the body of the indictment 
  would certainly make the indictment more definite and certain. However, the 
  indictment in question, when practically viewed, contained the necessary elements 
  of the offense and was clearly sufficient to apprise Gonzales of the charges 
  he was to answer in court.Â  Thus, the circuit court had subject matter jurisdiction 
  to convict Gonzales of the charged offense.
II.Â  Admissibility of Evidence Concerning the 
  Investigation of Appellant
Gonzales next argues the testimony of Fox and 
  Solomon singled him out as a particular subject of a police investigation and 
  therefore improperly called into question his character.Â  Gonzales contends 
  this admission of testimony was reversible error on the part of the trial court.Â  
  We disagree.
Rule 404, SCRE, limits the circumstances when 
  a defendantâ€™s character may be properly brought into evidence.Â  Subsection (a) 
  of the rule reads in relevant part: â€œEvidence of a personâ€™s character or a trait 
  of character is not admissible for the purpose of proving action in conformity 
  therewith on a particular occasion.â€Â  Pursuant to this rule, South Carolina 
  courts have held that while â€œ[e]vidence that police began an investigation because 
  of reports of criminal activity [is] admissible . . . , identification of an 
  individual as the suspect of a criminal investigation, based upon speculation 
  and effectively calling into question that individualâ€™s character, is not.â€Â  
  State v. Jones, 343 S.C. 562, 575, 541 S.E.2d 813, 820 (2001) (citations 
  omitted).
At trial, Officer Fox testified concerning his 
  initial questioning of Solomon as follows:

Q:Â  And what are you trying â€“ are you trying to determine 
  at [the initial questioning of an informant], if this person can be of use to 
  you?
A:Â  Yes, sir, basically . . . we want to know if they are 
  aware of actors in the drug trade that may be of interest or that can produce 
  drugs to this person.
Q:Â  And during this debriefing did the name [of Gonzales] 
  come up?

Before Fox could respond to this line of questioning, Gonzales 
  objected and the jury was sent from the courtroom.Â  After hearing arguments 
  by both counsel, the trial judge reiterated his pretrial ruling on this issue, 
  namely that the prosecution could continue to elicit testimony regarding the 
  meeting between Fox and Solomon but was to carefully avoid any reference to 
  Gonzalesâ€™s prior criminal convictions or any specific behavior regarding drug 
  sales. Â The State was to limit all questioning to the alleged transaction 
  at issue at trial.Â  
After the jury was allowed back into the courtroom, Foxâ€™s 
  testimony returned only briefly to Gonzalesâ€™s status as a criminal suspect:

Q: In your discussions with Mr. Solomon, were you able to 
  make a determination as to whether or not he could contact [Gonzales] for you?
A:Â  Yes
Q: Were you able to make a â€“ and what was that determination?
A: He knew him personally and knew how to reach him.
. . . . 
A: This was an attempt to conduct an investigation that 
  would result in an arrest and confiscation of illegal drugs.
Q:Â  From [Gonzales]?
A:Â  Correct.

We conclude the above testimony was not 
  admitted in error because Gonzalesâ€™s identification as a suspect of this investigation 
  was not â€œbased on speculation,â€ nor did this identification â€œeffectively [call] 
  into question [Gonzalesâ€™s] character.â€Â  Jones, 343 S.C. at 575, 541 S.E.2d 
  at 820.Â  Before Gonzales was identified to the jury as a criminal suspect due 
  to his known reputation as an â€œactor in the drug trade,â€ an objection was made, 
  and the jury was sent from the courtroom.Â  At no time did testimony reveal to 
  the jury that the police began their investigation of Gonzales because of speculative 
  reports that Gonzales was a known drug dealer or a person of criminal character.Â  
  Later testimony instead reflected that Gonzales became a suspect because of 
  the specific personal knowledge of Fox that the informant could, on this particular 
  occasion only, purchase illegal drugs from Gonzales.Â  
The purpose of Rule 404 is to exclude evidence that tends 
  to prove a defendantâ€™s guilt based merely on his reputation or character, i.e. 
  evidence which implies â€œbecause this person is a bad guy or acted in a manner 
  similar to this before, he is guilty.â€Â Â  Therefore, evidence that shows a defendant 
  was singled out as a particular suspect in a criminal investigation merely because 
  of his character or reputation is inadmissible.Â  See Jones, 343 
  S.C. at 574-76, 541 S.E.2d at 819-20 (finding testimony which singled out defendant 
  as a murder suspect merely because of reports he held a â€œgrudgeâ€ inadmissible); 
  German, 325 S.C. at 26-28, 478 S.E.2d at 688-89 (finding testimony that 
  defendant was a criminal suspect due to generalized reports that he was a drug 
  dealer inadmissible).Â  Had Fox answered counselâ€™s question and identified Gonzales 
  as a known â€œactor in the drug trade,â€ Rule 404 would clearly have been triggered 
  in this case.Â  However, because an objection was made and the question was not 
  answered, Gonzalesâ€™s character was never effectively questioned.Â  What Jones 
  and its ilk prohibit is not evidence that a defendant was once considered a 
  suspect in the particular criminal investigation which led to the defendantâ€™s 
  arrest, but evidence a defendant was made a suspect due to generalized reports 
  of his character or past conduct. 
In the case at bar, all testimony concerning Gonzalesâ€™s 
  status as the suspect of this criminal investigation was based on the personal 
  knowledge of informant Solomon that he could purchase drugs from Gonzales on 
  a specific occasion.Â  Testimony regarding personal knowledge of a particular 
  criminal transaction is not character evidence and therefore not inadmissible 
  under Rule 404, SCRE.Â Â  Accordingly, we conclude that the admission of the testimony 
  at issue was proper.
CONCLUSION
Because we find that the trial court had subject matter 
  jurisdiction to convict Gonzales and that the disputed testimony was not inadmissible 
  under Rule 404, SCRE, the decision of the trial court is
AFFIRMED.
 HEARN, C.J., STILWELL, J. and CURETON, A.J., concur.

 
   [1]  At trial, Officer Fox explained that drugs are 
    often wrapped â€œwith any type of scented objectâ€ to conceal the odor of drugs 
    from a trained drug dog.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Teresa Stone, Claimant/Employee,       
Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Traylor Brothers, Inc., Employer, and St. Paul's Fire & Marine Insurance 
        Co., Carrier,        Appellants.
      
    
  


Appeal From Horry County
Steven H. John, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 3841
Heard April 6, 2004 â€“ Filed July 6, 
  2004
Revised July 7, 2004

REVERSED


  
    
      
James R. Courie and R. Mark Davis, of Columbia, for Appellants.
Ian D. Maguire, of Myrtle Beach and John S. Nichols, of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  

BEATTY, J.:Â  In this workersâ€™ compensation 
  action, Traylor Brothers, Inc. and St. Paul Insurance Company appeal a circuit 
  courtâ€™s finding that Teresa Stone was entitled to benefits for injuries she 
  sustained when her estranged boyfriend assaulted her at work. We reverse.
FACTS
Teresa Stone (â€œClaimantâ€) and Kevin Stone (â€œStoneâ€) 
  began a relationship in July of 1998. 
  [1]  The two apparently started living together in October of that year. 
  [2]  The relationship became difficult and was â€œall over and done withâ€ 
  by the Christmas holidays. Claimant however continued living with Stone. While 
  still living together, Claimant and Stone started working for Traylor Brothers 
  (â€œEmployerâ€) in January of 1999. [3]  Two or three weeks later, Claimant spent five 
  nights away from the home she shared with Stone. The morning after the fifth 
  day, Claimant rode to work with a co-worker named Butch. When they arrived, 
  Stone approached Claimant as she was going to retrieve her work tools. The two 
  had a physical confrontation. The other workers separated them but they resumed 
  their fight and had to be separated a second time. Stone allegedly â€œsnatchedâ€ 
  Claimant by the hair, â€œpulled [her] across the parking lot,â€ and told her â€œwe 
  cannot work for the same company. You leave or I leave.â€ Stone also told a male 
  co-worker â€œLeave my lady alone.â€ 
Claimant sustained some injuries as a result of 
  the altercation and sought a hearing with the South Carolina Workersâ€™ Compensation 
  Commission (â€œthe Commissionâ€).Â  The commissioner concluded that Claimantâ€™s injuries 
  were not compensable.Â  The full Commission affirmed the findings. Claimant appealed 
  to the circuit court. That court reversed the decision, reasoning that it had 
  been reached without substantial evidence.Â  This appeal followed.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
In an appeal from the Commission, neither this 
  court nor the circuit court may substitute its judgment for that of the Commission 
  as to the weight of the evidence on questions of fact, but may reverse where 
  the decision is affected by an error of law.Â  Corbin v. Kohler Co., 351 
  S.C. 613, 617, 571 S.E.2d 92, 95 (Ct. App. 2002).Â  â€œAny review of the commissionâ€™s 
  factual findings is governed by the substantial evidence standard.â€Â  Lockridge 
  v. Santens of Am., Inc., 344 S.C. 511, 515, 544 S.E.2d 842, 844 (Ct. App. 
  2001). â€œSubstantial evidence is evidence that, in viewing the record as a whole, 
  would allow reasonable minds to reach the same conclusion that the full commission 
  reached.â€ Id. We review the Commissionâ€™s ruling only to determine whether 
  it is supported by substantial evidence or is controlled by some error of law. 
  SeeÂ  Corbin, 351 S.C. at 617, 571 S.E.2d at 95.Â Â Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
Appellant argues that the circuit court erred in 
  reversing theÂ  Commissionâ€™s decision. We agree.
To receive a workerâ€™s compensation award in South 
  Carolina, an employee must show that her injury arose â€œout ofâ€ and â€œin the course 
  of employment.â€Â  Howell v. Pac. Columbia Mills, 291 S.C. 469, 471, 354 
  S.E.2d 384, 385 (1987).Â  While the term â€œin the course ofâ€ refers to the time, 
  place, and circumstances of the accident, the term â€œarising out ofâ€ refers to 
  the origin or the cause of the accident.Â  Id.Â  An injury arises out of 
  oneâ€™s employment â€œwhen there is a causal connection between the conditions under 
  which the work is required to be performed and the resulting injury.â€Â  Broughton 
  v. S. of the Border, 336 S.C. 488, 497, 520 S.E.2d 634, 638 (Ct. App. 1999). 
  The injury need not be expected or even foreseeable, but â€œit must appear to 
  have had its origin in a risk connected with the employment, and to have flowed 
  from that source as a rational consequence.â€Â  Carter v. Penney Tire & 
  Recapping Co., 261 S.C. 341, 345, 200 S.E.2d 64, 65 (1973). 
Here, the dispute between Claimant and Stone originated 
  from their personal relationship. That relationship started deteriorating even 
  before Stone and Claimant started working for Employer. They had previously 
  fought at home and on other job sites. By all accounts, Stone was acting out 
  of jealously the morning he approached Claimant at work. There is clearly ample 
  support for the Commissionâ€™s decision. See Bright v. Orr-Lyons Mills, 
  285 S.C. 58, 61, 328 S.E.2d 68, 71 (1985) (holding that â€œwhen the dispute that 
  culminates in an assault arises out of the claimantâ€™s private life, the injury 
  is not ordinarily compensableâ€); Allsep v. Daniel Constr. Co., 216 S.C. 
  268, 270, 57 S.E.2d 427, 428 (1950) (excluding from coverage an injury â€œwhich 
  comes from a hazard to which the workmen would have been equally exposed apart 
  from the employmentâ€). 
Admittedly, the Commission could have reached a 
  different conclusion. However, that fact does not alter the scope of our inquiry. 
  See Palmetto Alliance, Inc. v. South Carolina Pub. Serv. Commâ€™n, 
  282 S.C. 430, 432, 319 S.E.2d 695, 696 (1984) (â€œ[The] possibility of drawing 
  two inconsistent conclusions from the evidence does not prevent an administrative 
  agencyâ€™s finding from being supported by substantial evidence.â€). We must consider 
  only whether the Commissionâ€™s decision is supported by substantial evidence.Â  
  We find that it is. Therefore, it must be affirmed.
Based on the foregoing, the circuit courtâ€™s decision is 
REVERSED.
HEARN, C.J., and ANDERSON, J., concur.

 
   [1]  Despite identical surnames, Teresa Stone and Kevin 
    Stone are not related by blood or marriage.

 
   [2]  At the time, they were both working for a company 
    other than Employer.

 
   [3]  Stone worked as a supervisor and Claimant, a welder; 
    however, Stone was not Claimantâ€™s supervisor.

THE 
  STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
  In The Court of Appeals
 
   
     
      
        Debra M. Therrell, 
          Appellant,
      
    
  

v.
 
   
     
      
        Jerryâ€™s Inc. d/b/a Jerryâ€™s 
          Travel Center, Employer, and American Alternative Insurance Company, 
          Carrier, Respondents.
      
    
  


Appeal From Clarendon 
  County
  Â Thomas W. Cooper, Jr., Circuit 
  Court Judge

Opinion No. 3843
  Heard June 9, 2004 - Filed July 12, 2004


AFFIRMED

 
   
     
      
        Robert David McKissick, and 
          William P. Hatfield, both of Florence, for Appellant.Â  
        Paul Linwood Hendrix, of 
          Spartanburg, for Respondents.
      
    
  

STILWELL, 
  J.:Â  In this workersâ€™ compensation case, Debra M. Therrell appeals the circuit 
  courtâ€™s order affirming the full commissionâ€™s determination that the injuries 
  to her right upper extremity are compensable as an injury to her arm rather 
  than to her shoulder.Â  We affirm.Â  
FACTS 

While employed as a waitress at Jerryâ€™s 
  Travel Stop in Clarendon County, Therrell slipped and fell, injuring her right 
  arm and shoulder.Â  
At 
  the hearing before the single commissioner, Therrell described the condition 
  of her right arm and shoulder following the accident.Â  She testified she had 
  difficulty performing everyday tasks such as washing clothes, operating a vacuum 
  cleaner, or getting dressed.Â  She was unable to lift things above her shoulder 
  level, requiring her to rely upon her co-workers to assist her in doing the 
  heavier parts of her job.Â  Therrell described experiencing â€œburning,â€ â€œgrinding,â€ 
  and â€œpoppingâ€ sensations in her right shoulder that were aggravated by repetitive 
  activities.Â  She also testified she has reduced strength in her right hand.Â  
  Even though she was right-hand dominant prior to the accident, she testified 
  her injury required her to rely primarily on her left hand and arm for tasks 
  associated with her job.Â  
The 
  single commissioner concluded Therrellâ€™s injury to her right upper extremity 
  resulted in permanent partial disability of twenty percent pursuant to S.C. 
  Code Ann. Â§ 42-9-30 (Supp. 2003), the section prescribing compensation for specific, 
  scheduled body parts.Â  Therrell appealed the award to the full commission, arguing 
  inter alia the commissioner erred in concluding the injury was 
  to her arm rather than her shoulder.Â  The full commission affirmed the award 
  of the single commissioner, adopting her findings of fact, but increasing Therrellâ€™s 
  permanent disability rating from twenty percent to thirty percent.Â  The circuit 
  court affirmed the full commissionâ€™s findings.Â  
STANDARD OF REVIEW 

Our review 
  of a decision of the workersâ€™ compensation commission is governed by the Administrative 
  Procedures Act.Â  Lark v. Bi-Lo, Inc., 276 S.C. 130, 133, 276 S.E.2d 304, 
  305 (1981).Â  Although this court may not substitute its judgment for that of 
  the full commission as to the weight of the evidence on questions of fact, we 
  may reverse where the decision is affected by an error of law.Â  S.C. Code Ann. 
  Â§ 1-23-380(A)(6) (Supp. 2003).
LAW/ANALYSIS 

The question before us is whether 
  the commission properly classified Therrellâ€™s injury compensable as a scheduled 
  body member pursuant to South Carolina Code section 42-9-30 (Supp. 2003). [1]  Â The answer is in the affirmative.Â  
Section 42-9-30 sets forth a schedule 
  prescribing the amount of compensation to be awarded for loss of various, specifically 
  enumerated body parts and organs.Â  Compensation for injuries to body parts not 
  covered by the statute has been prescribed by the workersâ€™compensation commission 
  under Regulation 67-1101.Â  For all other unscheduled injuries, section 42-9-30(20) 
  provides:Â  â€œFor the total or partial loss of, or loss of use of, a member, organ 
  or part of the body not covered herein and not covered under Â§Â§ 42-9-10 or 42-9-20, 
  sixty-six and two thirds of the average weekly wages not to exceed five hundred 
  weeks.â€Â  
In this case, the single commissioner 
  awarded compensation to Therrell under section 42-9-30(13), which provides: 
  â€œFor the loss of an arm, sixty-six and two-thirds percent of the average weekly 
  wages during two hundred twenty weeks.â€Â  Therrell claims this was error.Â  She 
  asserts the injury was to her shoulder, not to her arm.Â  Therefore, because 
  the shoulder is not among the body parts listed in section 42-9-30, Therrell 
  argues her disability was instead governed by the catch-all provision of 42-9-30(20) 
  which would potentially allow for a longer period of compensationâ€”up to 500 
  weeks rather than the maximum of 220 weeks scheduled for the loss of an arm.Â  
  
Therrell asserts that the cases of 
  Gilliam v. Woodside Mills, 312 S.C. 523, 435 S.E.2d 872 (Ct. App. 1993), 
  overruled on other grounds, 319 S.C. 385, 461 S.E.2d 818 (1995), and 
  Roper v. Kimbrellâ€™s of Greenville, Inc., 231 S.C. 453, 99 S.E.2d 
  52 (1957), lend support to her position.Â  Her reliance on these cases is misplaced.Â  
  In Gilliam, the issue before the court was whether the claimant suffered 
  injuries to more than one part of the body.Â  The compensable accident damaged 
  Gilliamâ€™s right knee and hip, requiring a total hip replacement.Â  The court 
  determined these were multiple injuries justifying an award for permanent and 
  total disability pursuant to section 42-9-10 (Supp. 2003).Â  In contrast, Therrell 
  offered no evidence that she sustained more than one injury.Â  
The Roper 
  court affirmed an award of loss of use to both arms, even though there was no 
  direct injury to the arms themselves.Â  The Roper court held the determination 
  was an issue of fact, stating nothing â€œin the statute relating to workmenâ€™s 
  compensation suggests restriction of their meaning to such total or partial 
  loss of use as has resulted from a direct injury to the member itself.â€Â  Roper, 
  231 S.C. at 456, 99 S.E.2d at 54.Â  
In deciding whether to award compensation 
  as for a scheduled injury as opposed to a non-scheduled general disability, 
  our supreme court has held:
 
  
    The commission may award compensation 
      to a claimant under the scheduled loss statute rather than the general disability 
      statutes so long as there is substantial evidence to support such an award.
    An award under the scheduled 
      loss statute, however, is premised upon the threshold requirement that the 
      claimant prove a loss, or loss of use of, a specific â€œmember, organ, or 
      part of the body.â€
  

Fields 
  v. Owens Corning Fiberglas, 301 S.C. 554, 555-56, 393 S.E.2d 172, 173 (1990) 
  (citation omitted). 
Based on our review of the record, 
  we conclude there is substantial evidence to support the commissionâ€™s finding 
  that Therrellâ€™s injury was properly compensable under section 49-2-30 as a scheduled 
  loss to an arm.Â  Therrellâ€™s own testimony indicates her injury affected the 
  use of her right arm, not her shoulder alone.Â  She described her injury as curtailing 
  her ability to use her right hand and armâ€”essentially requiring her to become 
  left-hand dominant rather than right-hand dominant as she had been before.Â  
  Moreover, we note Therrellâ€™s treating physician rated her injury as an impairment 
  of the â€œright upper extremity.â€Â  
For these reasons, we find Therrellâ€™s 
  injury was properly classified as the â€œloss of use of an armâ€ under section 
  42-9-30(13).Â  The ruling of the circuit court affirming the commission is therefore
AFFIRMED.
HEARN, C.J., and CURETON, A.J., 
  concur.

 
   [1] Â  Â Â Â Â Â  Section 42-9-30 was amended on February 3, 2004.Â  However, 
    the statute in effect at the time of the incident is controlling and governs 
    this case.Â

title: McGirt v. Nelson
description: James McGirt, as personal representative of the Estate of Bessie P. Haile appeals the circuit court's ruling regarding a survivorship clause in Haile's husband Last Will and Testament.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
James McGirt, as Personal Representative of the Estate of Bessie P.
Haile, Appellant,
v.
Richard H. Nelson, Ivan Nelson, Anthony L. Nelson and Don H. Nelson, 
        II, Respondents.
      
    
  


Appeal From Kershaw County
Â J. Ernest Kinard, Jr., Circuit Court 
  Judge

Opinion No. 3844
Heard March 10, 2004 â€“ Filed July 12, 
  2004

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
W. Steven Johnson and William M. Reynolds, III, both of 
  Columbia, for Appellant.
Arthur C. McFarland, of Charleston; Veronica G. Small, of 
  North Charleston; for Respondents.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  In this action, 
  James McGirt, as personal representative of the Estate of Bessie P. Haile (â€œthe 
  Estateâ€), appeals the order of the circuit court construing the last will and 
  testament of Richard H. Haile, Jr.Â  We affirm.
FACTS
The Estate brought an action 
  in probate court for a declaratory judgment construing the terms of Richardâ€™s 
  last will and testament, particularly regarding the proper ownership of Richardâ€™s 
  business upon the death of his wife, Bessie.Â  After the case was removed from 
  the probate court to the circuit court, the parties submitted the matter for 
  adjudication on briefs and joined together in submitting a stipulation of facts.Â  
  Those relevant to the determination of this case are as follows:

  
    
      
         1.  
         Richard executed his last will and testament on 
  May 27, 1971.
      
      
         2. 
         Richard died testate on December 25, 1976.
      
      
         3.    
         Richard was survived by his wife of 40+ years, Bessie, 
  and his daughter, Sylvia L. Haile (Sylvia H. Nelson at the time of Richardâ€™s 
  death).
      
      
         4. 
         Sylvia died testate on September 24, 1996.
      
      
         5.  
         The last will and testament of Sylvia devised her 
  estate to her sons, Richard, Ivan, Anthony, and Don Nelson (collectively, â€œRespondentsâ€).
      
      
         6. 
         Bessie died testate on May 26, 2001.
      
      
         7.  
         The last will and testament of Bessie makes each 
  Respondent a $1,000 bequest and devises the rest and residue of her estate to 
  Ralph Haile, the un-adopted child of her and Richard.
      
      
         8.  
         At the time of Richardâ€™s death, he owned an unincorporated 
  business known as Haileâ€™s Funeral Home (â€œthe businessâ€), which provided funeral 
  services to the public of Kershaw County.
      
    
  

This case hinges on the 
  construction of Richardâ€™s last will and testament. The provisions of this document 
  relevant to the determination of this case are as follows:

Item II:Â  I will, devise and bequeath my business to my wife, 
  [Bessie], and my daughter, [Sylvia], to share and share alike.
Item III:Â Â Â Â Â Â  It is my desire that Haileâ€™s Funeral Home 
  be maintained and operated under the name of Haileâ€™s Funeral Home.
Item IV:Â  In the event my wife, [Bessie], or my daughter, 
  [Sylvia], should predecease the other in death, then the survivor shall inherit 
  the whole.
Item V:Â  I so direct that my wife, [Bessie], during her life, 
  is vested with full discretion in the operation, control and style of [the business] 
  and I so direct that my said wife, [Bessie], shall file a written accounting, 
  at the beginning of each fiscal year, indicating the profit and expenses of 
  the business and at that time pay to my daughter, [Sylvia], her proportionate 
  share in accord with her pro rata interest in the business.
Item IX:Â  All the rest and remainder of my estate, both real 
  and personal, of whatever kind or nature and wheresoever situated, I will, devise 
  and bequeath unto my beloved wife [Bessie], and my beloved daughter, [Sylvia], 
  to share and share alike.

Respondents claim they 
  own a one-half interest in the business by way of their motherâ€™s will.Â  The 
  Estate claims sole ownership of the business by virtue of Item IV of the will 
  and the death of Sylvia before Bessie.Â  The circuit court found Richard Haileâ€™s 
  will vested a one-half interest in the funeral home business to each Bessie 
  and Sylvia.Â  The court further found that Sylviaâ€™s interest in the business 
  was properly transferred to Respondents. The Estate now appeals.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
This appeal involves stipulated 
  and undisputed facts; therefore this court is free to review whether the trial 
  court properly applied the law to those facts.Â  WDW Props. v. City of Sumter, 
  342 S.C. 6, 10, 535 S.E.2d 631, 632 (2000).Â  We are under no obligation in this 
  case to defer to the trial courtâ€™s legal conclusions. See J.K.Constr., 
  Inc. v. W. Carolina Regâ€™l Sewer Auth., 336 S.C. 162, 166, 519 S.E.2d 561, 
  563 (1999).
LAW / ANALYSIS
The Estate contends the 
  lower court erred in construing Richardâ€™s Will, particularly the survivorship 
  language in Item IV.Â  We disagree.
It is the cardinal rule 
  of will construction that the testatorâ€™s intent should be ascertained and followed 
  unless it violates some well-established rule of law. See Peopleâ€™s 
  Natâ€™l Bank of Greenville v. Harrison, 198 S.C. 457, 461, 18 S.E.2d 1, 3 
  (1941); Wates v. Fairfield Forest Prods. Co., 210 S.C. 319, 322, 42 S.E.2d 
  529, 530 (1947).Â  In ascertaining the testatorâ€™s intent, effect must be given 
  to every part of the will. If possible by any reasonable interpretation, â€œall 
  clauses must be harmonized with each other and with the will as a whole.â€ Shevlin 
  v. Colony Lutheran Church, 227 S.C. 598, 603, 88 S.E.2d 674, 677 (1955).Â  

In Richardâ€™s will, the 
  business was devised upon his death to Sylvia and Bessie to â€œshare and share 
  alike.â€ When read alone, this is an unambiguous and absolute grant of half of 
  the business to each.Â  The Estate contends, however, that the language in Item 
  IV cut down this absolute grant to either a joint tenancy with right of survivorship, 
  a life estate with cross remainder, or a fee simple subject to shifting executory 
  interest. [1] Â Â Â  
While the language in Item IV contemplates 
  the possibility of either Bessie or Sylvia predeceasing the other, we do not 
  believe Richard intended this language to cut down the devise of Item II into 
  something less than an absolute grant.Â  â€œ[W]here an estate or interest is given 
  in words of clear and ascertained legal signification, it shall not be enlarged, 
  cut down, or destroyed by superadded words in the same or subsequent clauses, 
  unless they raise an irresistible inference that such was the intention.â€Â  Schroder 
  v. Antipas, et al., 215 S.C. 552, 556, 56 S.E.2d 354, 355 (1949) (quoting 
  Adams, et al. v. Verner, 102 S.C. 7, 11, 86 S.E. 211, 212 (1915)).Â  
â€œ[A]n estate devised in fee cannot 
  by subsequent language be stripped of its legal incidents, and where it 
  appears that the controlling intention is to give an absolute estate, subsequent 
  language inconsistent therewith must be held ineffective.â€Â  Rogers v. Rogers, 
  221 S.C. 360, 368-369, 70 S.E.2d 637, 641 (1952). Â In some circumstances, an 
  absolute grant may be cut down by subsequent language in a will.Â  However, this 
  subsequent language must be â€œat least as clear in expressing that intention 
  as the words in which the interest is given.â€Â  Johnson v. Waldrop, 256 
  S.C. 372, 376, 182 S.E.2d 730, 731 (1971) (quoting Walker v. Alverson, 
  87 S.C. 55, 68 S.E. 966 (1910)).Â  Words of doubtful import following a gift 
  made in clear and unequivocal terms cannot cut down or qualify that gift.Â  See 
  Johnson, 256 S.C. at 376, 182 S.E.2d at 731; Wates v. Fairfield Forest 
  Prods. Co., 210 S.C. 319, 322, 42 S.E.2d 529, 530 (1947).Â  
In reviewing Item IV, it appears 
  Richard intended either Bessie or Sylvia to take the business as a sole owner 
  should one predecease the other before his death. However, considering the absolute 
  grant of Item II, this intent becomes less clear upon the death of Bessie or 
  Sylvia after Richardâ€™s death. In this circumstance, the language of Item IV 
  constitutes, at the very least, words of doubtful import less clear than the 
  original grant.
The Estate contends that 
  the facts and outcome of Johnson are analogous to this case. We find 
  this reliance misguided. The will in Johnson devised all of testatorâ€™s 
  property to his wife, but later stated that â€œupon the death of [his] wifeâ€ all 
  remaining property would be divided between his sister and brother.Â  256 S.C. 
  at 374, 182 S.E.2d at 730.Â  The controlling distinction between Johnson 
  and the case before this court is that in Johnson the added provision 
  was not of doubtful import.Â  The subsequent language in that case clearly contemplates 
  the ultimate divestment of the testatorâ€™s property upon the future date of his 
  wifeâ€™s death, not the date of his own. Item IV of Richardâ€™s will, however, contains 
  no similar reflection of testator intent.Â  
The issue before this court is one 
  of timing. We must decide, considering the will as a whole, at what point Richard 
  intended the absolute grant of Item II to vest permanently with his wife and 
  daughter.Â  Words concerning the intended time of vesting for a testamentary 
  devise usually refer to one of three dates: (1) the date of the will, (2) the 
  date of testatorâ€™s death, or (3) the date of the death of a life tenant.Â  See 
  Matter of Will of Hall, 318 S.C. 188, 193, 456 S.E.2d 439, 442 (Ct. App. 
  1995).Â  As further reflected in Item V, it was Richardâ€™s intent that the devise 
  of Item II was to take full possessory effect on the date of his death.Â  It 
  is well established in South Carolina that whenever a devise â€œtakes effect in 
  possession immediately on testatorâ€™s death, words of survivor-ship [sic] refer 
  to the date of testatorâ€™s death and are intended to provide for the contingency 
  of the death of the objects of his bounty in his lifetime; unless some other 
  point of time be indicated by the will.â€Â  Peecksen et al. v. Peecksen et 
  al., 211 S.C. 543, 549, 34 S.E.2d 787, 790 (1945).Â  
Although Haileâ€™s will contains words 
  of survivorship, it did not clearly indicate the point in time when the words 
  of survivorship would take effect.Â  As a result, the rule espoused in Peecksen 
  requires construing the words of survivorship to refer to the date of the testatorâ€™s 
  death and are only applicable in the event of an heir predeceasing the testator.Â  
  In Johnson, the point of time was clearly indicated by the will; here 
  it was not.Â  Moreover, this absence of point in time clarity renders the language 
  in Item IV to be of doubtful import, thus not effective in cutting down the 
  absolute grant of Item II.Â  
Accordingly, we find that Richard 
  only intended the survivor of Bessie and Sylvia to inherit the whole business 
  if one should predecease the other before his own death.Â  Since this did not 
  occur, Sylvia inherited an absolute one-half interest in the business, which 
  she transferred to Respondents through her will.
For the foregoing reasons, the circuit 
  courtâ€™s order is
AFFIRMED.
HEARN, C.J., ANDERSON and BEATTY, JJ., concur.

 
   
    [1]  Our analysis is limited to the general issue of whether the testator 
    intended any of these to apply.Â  Since any one of these interests would grant 
    the Estate present sole ownership of the business, we need not decide which 
    might be the most applicable. See Davis v. Davis, 223 S.C. 182, 
    192, 75 S.E.2d 46, 50 (1953).Â

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Kevin McCrowey,       
Appellant,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
The Zoning Board of Adjustment of the city of Rock Hill, South Carolina,       
Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From York County
John C. Hayes, III, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 3845
Submitted May 13, 2004 â€“ Filed July 
  12, 2004

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
R. Chadwick Smith, of Rock Hill, for Appellant.
W. Mark White, of Rock Hill, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Kevin McCrowey (â€œAppellantâ€) 
  appeals a circuit court ruling sustaining the decision of the Zoning Board of 
  Adjustment of Rock Hill (â€œRespondentâ€), which found Appellantâ€™s business to 
  be in violation of local zoning ordinances.Â  We affirm.  
  [1]   
FACTS
Kevin McCrowey is the owner of 
  property (the â€œPropertyâ€) located at 1151 Saluda Street in Rock Hill.Â  On 
  March 24, 1998, Appellant submitted an application for a Certificate of Occupancy 
  along with a diagram of the building located on the Property.Â  In March 1999, 
  Rock Hill granted Appellant a Certificate of Occupancy for the operation of 
  a pool hall.Â  
At the time Appellant submitted the application, 
  he was leasing the Property.Â  Appellant later subleased the Property to Carlondo 
  Brown, who was granted a Commercial Zoning Permit to operate a game room on 
  October 29, 1999.Â  In February 2000, Appellant purchased the Property.Â  On October 
  20, 2000 Appellant obtained a Certificate of Zoning Compliance for the operation 
  of a sports bar under the name of Infinity 2000 Sports Lounge.Â  
One of Rock Hillâ€™s inspectors noted on the Application 
  for Certificate of Zoning Compliance that the parking lot did not conform to 
  the zoning codeâ€™s design standards, as it appeared the Property did not have 
  enough parking spaces available to accommodate a nightclub. Â This notation also 
  requested the submission of a parking plan for the site.Â  Appellant submitted 
  the requested parking plan and an additional notation was later added by Rock 
  Hillâ€™s zoning administrator stating that the application was â€œ[a]pproved for 
  zoning compliance per plan revised [November 10, 2000].â€Â  
However, despite this apparent approval, the same 
  zoning administrator who approved Appellantâ€™s parking plan issued a Notice of 
  Violation to Appellant on September 6, 2001, which stated that the parking area 
  and signs located on the Property were in violation of Rock Hillâ€™s Zoning Code.Â  
  Appellant filed a notice of appeal on September 21, 2001 and a hearing was held 
  before the Rock Hill Board of Zoning Appeals (the â€œBoardâ€) on November 20, 2001.Â  

Despite the fact that he previously found 
  Appellantâ€™s parking plan in compliance with the applicable zoning ordinance, 
  the zoning administrator stated at the hearing that the Property did not currently, 
  nor did it ever, comply with the zoning ordinance since the nightclubs were 
  first opened on the property in 1998.Â  On January 11, 2002, the Board issued 
  a letter denying Appellantâ€™s appeal and affirming the decision of the zoning 
  administrator.Â  
Accordingly on February 8, 2002, Appellant 
  appealed the Boardâ€™s decision to the circuit court pursuant to S.C. Code Ann. 
  Â§ 6-29-820 (Supp. 2002). [2] Â  
  At the hearing before the circuit court, Appellant argued that Respondent should 
  be estopped from finding the Property in violation of the zoning ordinances 
  based on its earlier conduct.Â  Appellant offered this argument, in part, based 
  on the fact that nightclubs have operated on the Property since 1998 without 
  incident and all with approval of Respondent.Â  In addition, as noted above, 
  the zoning administrator who issued the Notice of Violation previously approved 
  Appellantâ€™s parking plan.Â  Therefore, Appellant averred he relied on this past 
  conduct to his detriment when he decided to purchase the Property.Â  
Relying on several South Carolina authorities, 
  Respondent averred that under the facts of this case, the doctrine of equitable 
  estoppel should not be applied.Â  By order dated May 23, 2002, the trial court 
  agreed with Respondent and affirmed the Boardâ€™s decision.Â  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
Because Rock Hill enacted the zoning ordinance 
  in question pursuant to the South Carolina Local Government Comprehensive Planning 
  Enabling Act of 1994, the scope of review is governed by statute.Â  See 
  S.C. Code Ann. Â§Â§ 6-29-310 â€“ 1200 (Supp. 2002). Accordingly, as stated in Section 
  840, â€œ[t]he findings of fact by the board of appeals shall be treated in the 
  same manner as a finding of fact by a jury.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 6-29-840 (Supp. 
  2002); see also Heilker v. Zoning Bd. of Appeals for City of Beaufort, 
  346 S.C. 401, 405, 552 S.E.2d 42, 44 (Ct. App. 2001).Â  Furthermore, â€œ[i]n determining 
  the questions presented by the appeal, the court shall determine only whether 
  the decision of the board is correct as a matter of law.â€Â  Id.  
It is important to note â€œ[a] court will 
  refrain from substituting its judgment for that of the reviewing body, even 
  if it disagrees with the decision.â€Â  Restaurant Row Assocs. v. Horry County, 
  335 S.C. 209, 216, 516 S.E.2d 442, 446 (1999) (citation omitted).Â  â€œHowever, 
  a decision of a municipal zoning board will be overturned if it is arbitrary, 
  capricious, has no reasonable relation to a lawful purpose, or if the board 
  has abused its discretion.â€Â  Id.Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS



 
 Appellant argues the trial court erred 
  in finding the doctrine of equitable estoppel not applicable because the zoning 
  administrator erroneously issued a certificate of zoning compliance.Â  We disagree.Â 
Typically, equitable estoppel is found 
  to exist when the following elements are present:

(1) [C]onduct by the party estopped which amounts to a false 
  representation or concealment of material facts or which is calculated to convey 
  the impression that the facts are otherwise than and inconsistent with those 
  which the party subsequently attempts to assert; (2) the intention or at least 
  expectation that such conduct shall be acted upon by the other party; (3) knowledge, 
  actual or constructive, of the true facts; (4) lack of knowledge or the means 
  of knowledge of the facts by the other party; (5) reliance upon the conduct 
  by the other party; and (6) a detrimental change of position by the other party 
  because of his reliance. 

Oswald v. Aiken County, 281 S.C. 298, 305, 315 S.E.2d 
  146, 151 (Ct. App. 1984) (citing Frady v. Smith, 247 S.C. 353, 147 S.E.2d 
  412 (1966)).
 However, it is generally held that â€œ[n]o 
  estoppel can grow out of dealings with public officers of limited authority, 
  and the doctrine of equitable estoppel cannot ordinarily be invoked to defeat 
  a municipality in the prosecution of its public affairs because of an error 
  or mistake of . . . one of its officers or agents . . . .â€ DeStefano v. City 
  of Charleston, 304 S.C. 250, 257-258, 403 S.E.2d 648, 653 (1991) (quoting 
  Farrow v. City Council of Charleston, 169 S.C. 373, 382, 168 S.E. 852, 
  855 (1933)) (further citations omitted).Â  See also South Carolina 
  Coastal Council v. Vogel, 292 S.C. 449, 452, 357 S.E.2d 187, 189 (Ct. App. 
  1987) (holding that the doctrine of equitable estoppel cannot be used to deprive 
  the State of the due exercise of its police power or to frustrate its application 
  of public policy).
Significantly, in spite of this general 
  rule, South Carolina courts have held that â€œ[a] governmental body is not immune 
  from the application of equitable estoppel where its officers or agents act 
  within the proper scope of their authority.â€ Â South Carolina Coastal Council 
  v. Vogel, 292 S.C. 449, 453, 357 S.E.2d 187, 189 (Ct. App. 1987) (citing 
  Oswald v. Aiken County, 281 S.C. 298, 315 S.E.2d 146 (Ct. App. 1984)).Â  

Although Appellant acknowledges the general 
  rule, he argues the zoning administrator was acting within the proper scope 
  of his authority, and thus, the doctrine should be applicable.Â  Specifically, 
  Appellant avers that in the current case â€œthe Zoning Administrator acted within 
  his proper authorityÂ Â  when he concluded that [his] parking area met Rock Hillâ€™s 
  zoning requirements.â€Â  The Appellant goes on to state â€œthe decision of whether 
  a piece of property conforms to zoning compliance is a determination the zoning 
  administrator would appear to have authority to make.â€Â Â  
However, the zoning administrator did 
  not have the authority to alter or waive the zoning ordinance in question.Â  
  Rock Hillâ€™s Zoning Code gives zoning administrators the power to administer 
  and enforce the Zoning Code.Â  Rock Hillâ€™s Zoning Code does not grant power to 
  an administrator to alter, modify, or waive provisions contained in the Zoning 
  Code.Â  Further, the zoning administrator was not granted with the authority 
  to grant a variance.Â  The Zoning Code only grants the Zoning Board of Appeals 
  the discretion of whether and when to grant a variance.Â  Because the parties 
  do not dispute that the Property did in fact violate the zoning ordinance, the 
  zoning administrator exceeded his authority when he approved Appellantâ€™s parking 
  plan in October 2000.Â  As the zoning administratorâ€™s actions in approving Appellantâ€™s 
  parking plan were in error, the trial court did not err in concluding, based 
  on the authority cited above, that equitable estoppel could not be applied to 
  frustrate the attempts by Rock Hill to enforce its zoning code as written. 
CONCLUSION
Accordingly, based on the foregoing, the decision of the trial 
  court is 
AFFIRMED.
 HEARN, C.J., ANDERSON and BEATTY, JJ., 
  concur.

 
   [1] Â  Because oral argument would not aid the court 
    in resolving the issues on appeal, we decide this case without oral argument 
    pursuant to Rules 215 and 220(b)(2), SCACR.

 
    [2]  
  
  A person who may have a 
    substantial interest in any decision of the board of appeals or an officer 
    or agent of the appropriate governing authority may appeal from a decision 
    of the board to the circuit court in and for the county by filing with the
