THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Sandra Hargrove,       
Employee, Claimant,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Titan Textile Co. & Perdue Farms, Inc.,       
Employer,
And Kemper Insurance Co. & Perdue Farms, self-insured,       
Carrier, Defendants,
Of whom Perdue Farms, Inc. is the,       
Appellant,
And Sandra Hargrove, Titan Textile Co. and Kemper Insurance Co. are 
        the,        Respondents.
      
    
  


Appeal From Dillon County
A. Victor Rawl, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 3846
Heard June 10, 2004 â€“ Filed July 
  12, 2004

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Finley B. Clarke, of Florence, for Appellant.
Walter H. Barefoot, of Florence, for Respondents Titan 
  Textile Co. and Kemper Insurance Co.
William L. Smith, II, of Columbia, for Respondent Sandra 
  Hargrove.
      
    
  


ANDERSON, J.:Â  Perdue Farms, Inc. appeals 
  a Circuit Court order affirming the award of Workersâ€™ Compensation benefits 
  to Sandra Hargrove.Â  Perdue argues the Circuit Court erred in ruling substantial 
  evidence supported the finding by the Appellate Panel of the Workersâ€™ Compensation 
  Commission that Hargrove aggravated or exacerbated a pre-existing condition 
  during the course of her employment at Perdue.Â  We affirm.
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
Sandra Hargrove is a thirty-six-year-old mother 
  of two who resides in Dillon, South Carolina.Â  Hargrove began working at Titan 
  Textile Company, d/b/a Dillon Yarn (Dillon Yarn), as an inspector/packer in 
  December of 1997.Â  Hargroveâ€™s job at Dillon Yarn required her to remove spools 
  of yarn from manufacturing machines and visually inspect the spools before placing 
  them on a metal pole protruding from a pushcart.Â  Once the spool was on the 
  cart, she would wrap it in plastic and then, using both hands, remove the spool 
  from the pole and place it in a box located on the pushcart.Â  Hargrove â€œput 
  togetherâ€ fifty or more boxes per day.
A single box can hold any number of spools depending 
  on the size of the particular spool being manufactured.Â  When the cart was full, 
  Hargrove would push it to a conveyor belt where she would unload the boxes.Â  
  Hargrove testified she made approximately forty or fifty trips per shift to 
  the conveyor line.Â  Her supervisor at Dillon Yarn, Effie Peele, estimated Hargrove 
  would â€œhandle somewhere between 600 and 800 tubes of yarn per day.â€Â  During 
  her time at Dillon Yarn, Hargroveâ€™s work schedule consisted of working eight-hour 
  shifts, seven days in a row, having two or sometimes three days off, and then 
  working seven more days.
Hargrove stated she never experienced problems with 
  either of her arms before working at Dillon Yarn.Â  However, about six or seven 
  months after her employment at Dillon Yarn began, Hargrove started experiencing 
  problems with her left hand and arm, including swelling and numbness.Â  She did 
  not seek medical attention or notify her employer when these problems first 
  started.Â  She testified she would go home after work and soak her hand and arm 
  and then â€œit would be all rightâ€â€”â€œ[t]he pain would go awayâ€ and the â€œswelling 
  would go down.â€Â  According to Hargrove, this swelling would occur â€œas much as 
  once a month.â€
On March 1, 2000, Hargrove applied for a position 
  working first shift at Perdue Farms, a chicken processing plant.Â  On the medical 
  history section of her application, Hargrove was asked if she had ever â€œhad 
  pain, numbness, swelling in [her] hands, wrists, arms.â€Â  Hargrove indicated 
  that in the past she had problems with â€œsorenessâ€ due to lifting boxes at Dillon 
  Yarn.Â  She further noted a history of pain and swelling in her hand and wrist.
Prior to accepting an application, Perdueâ€™s practice 
  is to give the applicant a physical to see if the individual can physically 
  perform the job.Â  The physical consists of a number of tests specifically tailored 
  to the demands of the position being sought.Â  Hargrove was given tests to ascertain 
  her grip strength on both the right and left hands, in addition to other tests 
  on her hands including the Tinel, Phalen and Finklestein tests.Â  These three 
  tests check for numbness and tingling in the hands.Â  The Finklestein test involves 
  physically touching the median nerve to check for tingling.
The Occupational Health Nurse at Perdue, Mary Smith 
  Sutherland, declared all tests on Hargrove were negative.Â  Nurse Sutherland 
  explained that Hargroveâ€™s testing indicated she had a strong grip in both hands 
  and no problem taking any of the tests administered by Perdue.
Hargroveâ€™s grip strength was important because 
  she was applying for a position in the evisceration department.Â  Nurse Sutherland 
  stated that, in the evisceration department, employees have to pull skin off 
  of the chickens that are being processed.Â  She said that, although machines 
  have already processed the insides of the chickens, employees might have to 
  â€œscoopâ€ the remaining entrails from the birdâ€™s insides.Â  Nurse Sutherland professed 
  the tasks assigned to an employee in the evisceration department involve repetitive 
  work, â€œto some degree.â€
After Hargrove passed the physical, Perdue hired 
  her to work in the evisceration department.Â  Hargrove began her employment with 
  Perdue on March 13, 2000. [1] Â  The first week consisted of 
  orientation.Â  Nurse Sutherland testified Hargrove worked 25.61 hours her first 
  week.Â  The first day of her employment consisted of classroom training for the 
  entire day.Â  On each remaining day of her first week, Hargrove spent four hours 
  in the classroom and four hours on a training line.Â  Both Nurse Sutherland 
  and Hargrove testified that new employees could move more slowly on a training 
  line than on a regular line.
Hargrove worked 23.18 hours her second week.Â  Unlike 
  the previous week, she did not have any classroom training and spent all of 
  her time on a regular line, which processed 2,000 to 5,000 chickens each day.Â  
  Hargrove stated that although she was on a regular line, she did not move as 
  fast as other employees.Â  She declared that her job during this week consisted 
  of pulling the skin off of chickens and removing the remaining entrails from 
  the processed chickens.
On or around March 16, 2000, having finished her 
  shift at Perdue, Hargrove informed Peele, her supervisor at Dillon Yarn, that 
  she was experiencing pain in her left wrist and arm.Â  Hargrove did not tell 
  Peele she believed the problems with her arm were work-related and Peele did 
  not ask if they were.Â  According to Peele, this was the first time Hargrove 
  complained of pain in her hand and arm.Â  Hargrove made similar complaints to 
  Peele on at least two more occasions, although Peele did not keep a record of 
  the complaints.Â  Peele indicated Hargroveâ€™s â€œjob was repetitive.â€
On March 23, 2000, Hargrove worked her shift at 
  Perdue.Â  She testified that, after performing her usual job on the evisceration 
  line for a short time, the line went down and she was instructed to work in 
  the box room.Â  Her duties there consisted of retrieving the boxes others were 
  assembling in the room.Â  When her shift was over, Hargrove went to work her 
  second-shift position at Dillon Yarn.
After clocking in, but before working, Hargrove 
  noticed a funny feeling in the fingers on her left hand.Â  Hargrove declared 
  that nothing happened to her hand or arm between the time she left Perdue and 
  the time she arrived at Dillon Yarn that would explain the problems she began 
  having.
Hargrove stated she went to Dillon Yarnâ€™s nurse, 
  Joyce Harmon, and â€œasked [Harmon] about the funny feeling in [her] fingers.â€Â  
  Hargrove requested something for pain.Â  The nurse gave Hargrove some Tylenol 
  and then Hargrove went to work as usual.Â  As she was performing her normal duties, 
  Hargrove picked up a tube and it fell from her grasp.Â  She testified that after 
  she dropped the tube she looked down at her left hand and noticed it was swollen.Â  
  Hargrove went to her supervisor and asked if she could be excused to go see 
  a doctor.Â  She was given permission and went to see her family physician, Dr. 
  Michael Brown, the next day, March 24.
In his medical report, Dr. Brown noted: â€œHas tenderness 
  over the extensor surface left hand and also at base of the thumb.â€Â  Dr. Brown 
  x-rayed the hand, placed it in a splint, and prescribed medication.Â  He wrote 
  Hargrove an excuse from work for a few days.
On March 27, 2000, Hargrove went to the medical 
  department at Perdue to provide Dr. Brownâ€™s letter excusing her from work.Â  
  Nurse Sutherland professed she did not ask Hargrove whether the injury was work-related 
  because she did not feel Hargrove had worked at Perdue long enough to have experienced 
  an injury there.Â  Nevertheless, Nurse Sutherland reviewed Hargroveâ€™s file and 
  sent her to Perdueâ€™s company physician, Dr. Phil Wallace. [2] 
Dr. Wallaceâ€™s report, dated March 27, 2000, indicates 
  Hargroveâ€™s left wrist and hand showed â€œslight swelling.â€Â  He diagnosed â€œprobable 
  mild tendonitisâ€ and modified her activities for two weeks.Â  The report demonstrates 
  that Dr. Wallace â€œadvised [Hargrove] she probably needs to pick one or the other 
  jobâ€ because he did not â€œthink she [could] physically handle both.â€Â  Dr. Wallace 
  noted, under a section in the report subtitled â€œADD,â€ that he â€œ[t]alked with 
  Perdue, felt this was not probably W/C, situation where she is using too much 
  work in both _____.â€Â  Regarding this particular notation, the Single Commissioner 
  concluded:

The report does speak for itself.Â  A.D.D., I believe, based 
  on reading medical reports stands for addendum.Â  Meaning this is after he talked 
  with Perdue he added this.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  . . . .
Well, he doesnâ€™t say in the addendum [what his opinion is].Â  
  He says â€œtalked with Perdue.Â  Felt this was probably [not] W.C. situation where 
  sheâ€™s using too much work in both something.Â  They both agreed to give herâ€â€”he 
  doesnâ€™t say that thisâ€”whether this was his.Â  It looks to me like, â€œtalked with 
  Perdue.Â  Felt this was not probably W.C. like Perdue was saying it wasnâ€™t Workersâ€™ 
  Comp.

Dr. Wallace issued excuses from work, which Hargrove 
  took to both Dillon Yarn and Perdue. 
  [3] Â  On Hargroveâ€™s visit to Dillon Yarn, Harmon, the plant nurse, gave 
  her a long-term disability form to complete.Â  Hargrove testified she completed 
  the form and sent it to Dr. Wallace.Â  Harmon stated she talked to Dr. Wallace 
  and received the disability form back from him, which indicated Hargroveâ€™s problems 
  with her arm were work-related.Â  In response to the question on the form whether 
  the condition was â€œdue to injury or sickness arising out of patientâ€™s employment,â€ 
  Dr. Wallace checked the box after â€œYes.â€
On April 5, 2000, after noting Hargrove was continuing 
  to have pain and limitation of movement in her wrist, Dr. Wallace referred her 
  to Dr. Dwight Jacobus.Â  Dr. Jacobus, an orthopedic surgeon, is one of Perdueâ€™s 
  approved doctors for injuries that are work-related.Â  Dr. Jacobus first saw 
  Hargrove on April 7, 2000.Â  He testified that his â€œinitial impression, after 
  [he] took a history and physical, was that of a possible carpal tunnel syndrome 
  as it related to her left upper extremity.â€Â  Dr. Jacobus saw Hargrove on at 
  least four occasions and performed a number of tests and diagnostic studies 
  to determine the root cause of her problems.Â  Dr. Jacobus noted Hargrove continued 
  to experience pain and swelling in her left hand.Â  In a medical record dated 
  May 15, 2000, Dr. Jacobus stated: â€œI still find no specific clinical abnormality 
  other than some changes that possibly might represent an early reflex sympathetic 
  dystrophy.Â  I think a 2nd opinion is important and I have convinced her of that.â€
On January 18, 2001, Dr. Jacobus wrote a letter 
  to Hargroveâ€™s attorney which declared: â€œIt would be my opinion that the symptoms 
  related to the left upper extremity were most probably caused and aggravated 
  by repetitive activities related to her work.â€Â  In a later deposition, Dr. Jacobus 
  reaffirmed this opinion.Â  In fact, he specifically opined that Hargroveâ€™s 
  (1) â€œlong-term repetitious activitiesâ€ at Dillon Yarn â€œwould have been the activities 
  that instituted the changes leading to the diagnosis or at least the symptoms 
  of carpal tunnel syndromeâ€; and (2) â€œsecondary job responsibilities of stripping 
  chicken skinâ€ at Perdue â€œwould therefore possibly . . . exacerbate the symptoms 
  that were instituted by the initial employee responsibilities.â€
Because Hargrove was still complaining of pain 
  and discomfort, Dr. Jacobus felt it prudent to seek a second opinion.Â  Thus, 
  Hargrove was referred to Dr. Robert W. Moore, a physician in Florence, who specializes 
  in upper extremity problems.Â  Dr. Moore diagnosed Hargrove with reflex 
  sympathetic dystrophy in her left hand.Â  He suggested that Hargrove participate 
  in pain management, as well as hand therapy and several other treatments.Â  A 
  series of epidural blocks was performed.Â  Hargrove stated these treatments were 
  not helpful.
Responding to a letter from Hargroveâ€™s attorney, 
  Dr. Moore stated in a letter dated January 3, 2001, that it was his â€œopinion 
  that [Hargroveâ€™s] problem was not caused by the repetitive activities she performed 
  at Dillon Yarn.â€Â  Unable to make much progress towards Hargroveâ€™s improvement, 
  Dr. Moore referred Hargrove to Dr. James A. Nunley at the Duke University Medical 
  Center.Â  Dr. Nunley agreed that it â€œlooks like she does in fact have 
  reflex sympathetic dystrophy.â€Â  He noted she â€œshows the skin changes, the swelling.â€Â  
  Dr. Nunley suggested Hargrove be referred to Dr. L. Andrew Koman at Bowman Gray 
  Medical School Reflex Sympathetic Dystrophy Clinic.Â  Hargrove testified she 
  did not go to Bowman Gray.
On July 19, 2000, Hargrove filed a Form 50 seeking 
  Workersâ€™ Compensation benefits against Dillon Yarn alleging repetitive trauma 
  as the cause of her injuries.Â  Hargrove asserted that â€œ[d]ue to injury, the 
  claimant is in need of . . . medical examination and treatment for carpal tunnel 
  syndrome.â€Â  Dillon Yarn denied Hargrove was entitled to benefits.Â  Dillon Yarn 
  then moved to add Perdue as a co-defendant.Â  Perdue was joined as a party by 
  order dated December 14, 2001.Â  Both Dillon Yarn and Perdue claimed the injuries, 
  if work-related, happened when Hargrove was working for the other.
In her order, the Single Commissioner found the 
  following facts:

1.Â  Claimant sustained compensable injuries by accident 
  arising out of and in the course of her employment on March 23, 2000 with both 
  employers.
2.Â  The employment with Dillon Yarn (Titan Textile) caused 
  claimantâ€™s carpal tunnel syndrome.
3.Â  Claimantâ€™s employment with Perdue exacerbated her condition.
4.Â  The last date of injurious exposure occurred while the 
  employment relationship existed concurrently.
5.Â  It would be unfair to have one employer accept 100% 
  liability under a theory of last date of injurious exposure when the difference 
  in the last work dateâ€”not employment dateâ€”was only a matter of hours and included 
  a weekend.Â  Consideration is given also to the work schedule and how it may 
  have figured into dates worked.

The Commissioner concluded: â€œPursuant to Section 
  42-1-160, claimant sustained compensable injuries by accident on March 23, 2000 
  with both employers.â€Â  The Commissioner ruled that Hargrove was entitled to 
  temporary total disability as well as payment of medical expenses, to be split 
  evenly between the employers.
Both employers appealed this decision to an Appellate 
  Panel of the South Carolina Workersâ€™ Compensation Commission (the Appellate 
  Panel).Â  The Appellate Panel issued an order unanimously affirming the ruling 
  of the Single Commissioner in its entirety:

After careful review in the instant case, the Appellate Panel 
  has determined that all of the Hearing Commissionerâ€™s Findings of Fact and Rulings 
  of Law are correct as stated.Â  We find that such Findings of Fact and Conclusions 
  of Law are hereby included in this Order by reference . . . .Â  Accordingly, 
  the Findings of Fact and Conclusions of Law set forth in the single commissionerâ€™s 
  Order shall become, and hereby are, the law of the case; and, therefore, the 
  Order is sustained in its entirety.

The employers appealed the Appellate Panelâ€™s decision 
  to the Circuit Court.Â  The Circuit Court issued a form order affirming the decision.Â  
  Specifically, the Circuit Court found: â€œThere is substantial evidence to support 
  the Commissionâ€™s order and therefore it is affirmed.â€Â  Perdue appealed 
  the Circuit Courtâ€™s order to this Court. [4] 
STANDARD OF REVIEW
The South Carolina Administrative Procedures Act 
  (APA) establishes the standard for judicial review of decisions of the Workersâ€™ 
  Compensation Commission.Â  See Lark v. Bi-Lo, Inc., 276 S.C. 130, 
  276 S.E.2d 304 (1981); Gibson v. Spartanburg Sch. Dist. No. 3, 338 S.C. 
  510, 526 S.E.2d 725 (Ct. App. 2000).Â  A reviewing court may reverse or modify 
  a decision of an agency if the findings, inferences, conclusions or decisions 
  of that agency are â€œclearly erroneous in view of the reliable, probative and 
  substantial evidence on the whole record.â€Â  Bursey v. South Carolina Depâ€™t 
  of Health and Envtl. Control, Op. No. 3813 (S.C. Ct. App. filed June 1, 
  2004) (Shearouse Adv. Sh. No. 24 at 47); S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 1-23-380(A)(6)(e) 
  (Supp. 2003).Â  Under the scope of review established in the APA, this Court 
  may not substitute its judgment for that of the Commission as to the weight 
  of the evidence on questions of fact, but may reverse where the decision is 
  affected by an error of law.Â  Frame v. Resort Servs., Inc., 357 S.C. 
  520, 593 S.E.2d 491 (Ct. App. 2004); Stephen v. Avins Constr. Co., 324 
  S.C. 334, 478 S.E.2d 74 (Ct. App. 1996); S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 1-23-380(A)(6)(d) 
  (Supp. 2003).
The substantial evidence rule of the APA governs 
  the standard of review in a Workersâ€™ Compensation decision.Â  Frame, 357 
  S.C. at 527, 593 S.E.2d at 494; Corbin v. Kohler Co., 351 S.C. 613, 571 
  S.E.2d 92 (Ct. App. 2002).Â  This Courtâ€™s review is limited to deciding whether 
  the Commissionâ€™s decision is unsupported by substantial evidence or is controlled 
  by some error of law.Â  See Gibson, 338 S.C. at 517, 526 S.E.2d 
  at 728-29; see also Lyles v. Quantum Chem. Co. (Emery), 315 S.C. 440, 
  434 S.E.2d 292 (Ct. App. 1993) (noting that in reviewing decision of Workersâ€™ 
  Compensation Commission, Court of Appeals will not set aside its findings unless 
  they are not supported by substantial evidence or they are controlled by error 
  of law).
Substantial evidence is not a mere scintilla of 
  evidence, nor the evidence viewed blindly from one side of the case, but is 
  evidence which, considering the record as a whole, would allow reasonable minds 
  to reach the conclusion the administrative agency reached in order to justify 
  its action.Â  Etheredge v. Monsanto Co., 349 S.C. 451, 562 S.E.2d 679 
  (Ct. App. 2002); Broughton v. South of the Border, 336 S.C. 488, 520 
  S.E.2d 634 (Ct. App. 1999).Â  The Appellate Panel is the ultimate fact finder 
  in Workersâ€™ Compensation cases and is not bound by the Single Commissionerâ€™s 
  findings of fact.Â  Gibson, 338 S.C. at 517, 526 S.E.2d at 729; Muir 
  v. C.R. Bard, Inc., 336 S.C. 266, 519 S.E.2d 583 (Ct. App. 1999).Â  The final 
  determination of witness credibility and the weight to be accorded evidence 
  is reserved to the Appellate Panel.Â  See Shealy v. Aiken County, 
  341 S.C. 448, 535 S.E.2d 438 (2000); Parsons v. Georgetown Steel, 318 
  S.C. 63, 456 S.E.2d 366 (1995); Gibson, 338 S.C. at 517, 526 S.E.2d at 
  729.Â  The possibility of drawing two inconsistent conclusions from the evidence 
  does not prevent an administrative agencyâ€™s findings from being supported by 
  substantial evidence.Â  Sharpe v. Case Produce, Inc., 336 S.C. 154, 519 
  S.E.2d 102 (1999); Muir, 336 S.C. at 282, 519 S.E.2d at 591.Â  Where there 
  are conflicts in the evidence over a factual issue, the findings of the Appellate 
  Panel are conclusive.Â  Etheredge, 349 S.C. at 455, 562 S.E.2d at 681.
The findings of an administrative agency are presumed 
  correct and will be set aside only if unsupported by substantial evidence.Â  
  Anderson v. Baptist Med. Ctr., 343 S.C. 487, 541 S.E.2d 526 (2001); Hicks 
  v. Piedmont Cold Storage, Inc., 335 S.C. 46, 515 S.E.2d 532 (1999).Â  It 
  is not within our province to reverse findings of the Appellate Panel which 
  are supported by substantial evidence.Â  Broughton, 336 S.C. at 496, 520 
  S.E.2d at 637.Â  The appellate court is prohibited from overturning findings 
  of fact of the Appellate Panel, unless there is no reasonable probability the 
  facts could be as related by the witness upon whose testimony the finding was 
  based.Â  Etheredge, 349 S.C. at 455-56, 562 S.E.2d at 681.
In the current case, after â€œcareful review,â€ the 
  Appellate Panel found â€œthat all of the Hearing Commissionerâ€™s Findings of Fact 
  and Rulings of Law [were] correct as stated.â€Â  Thus, the Appellate Panel adopted 
  the Single Commissionerâ€™s findings of fact and rulings of law by reference into 
  its final order as it is entitled to do under sections 1-23-350 and 42-17-40 
  of the South Carolina Code.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§Â§ 1-23-350 (1986) & 
  42-17-40 (Supp. 2003); see also Eaddy v. Smurfit-Stone Container Corp., 
  355 S.C. 154, 584 S.E.2d 390 (Ct. App. 2003) (interpreting these statutory provisions 
  and concluding the Appellate Panel meets the requirements contained therein 
  when it incorporates a Single Commissionerâ€™s findings of fact and rulings of 
  law by reference into its order).
LAW/ANALYSIS
Perdueâ€™s sole argument on appeal is that 
  the Circuit Court erred in finding the Appellate Panelâ€™s decision was supported 
  by substantial evidence.Â  We disagree.
I.Â  Pee v. AVM
Perdue claims Hargrove did not attribute 
  her injury to her work at Perdue.Â  Perdue contends Hargrove â€œwas able to identify 
  a specific incident on March 23, 2000 at Dillon Yarn which caused an acute aggravation 
  of her underlying condition.â€Â  However, as Perdue acknowledges, it is 
  not necessary for a claimant to identify a specific precipitating event in order 
  for the claimant to be entitled to benefits.Â  Our Supreme Court addressed this 
  issue in Pee v. AVM, Inc., 352 S.C. 167, 573 S.E.2d 785 (2002):

Employer contends a repetitive trauma injury does not qualify 
  as an â€œinjury by accidentâ€ because the cause of the injury is not unexpected 
  and the injury lacks definiteness of time. . . . .
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  . . . .
As we more recently stated, â€œin determining whether 
  something constitutes an injury by accident the focus is not on some specific 
  event, but rather on the injury itself.â€Â  Stokes v. First Natâ€™l Bank, 
  306 S.C. 46, 50, 410 S.E.2d 248, 250 (1991).Â  Further, an injury is unexpected, 
  bringing it within the category of accident, if the worker did not intend it 
  or expect it would result from what he was doing.Â  Colvin [v. E.I. DuPont 
  De Nemours Co.], 227 S.C. at 468-69, 88 S.E.2d at 582 (emphasis added).Â  
  Therefore, if an injury is unexpected from the workerâ€™s point of view, it qualifies 
  as an injury by accident.Â  Here, there is no evidence Claimant intended or expected 
  to be injured as a result of her repetitive work activity.
Employerâ€™s contention that the cause of the injury 
  must be unexpected is incorrect.Â  Under South Carolina law, if the injury itself 
  is unexpected, it is compensable as an injury by accident.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  . . . .
Definiteness of time, while relevant to proving causation, 
  is not required to prove an injury qualifies as an injury by accident. For instance, 
  in Sturkie v. Ballenger Corp., 268 S.C. 536, 235 S.E.2d 120 (1977), we 
  found the claimantâ€™s emphysema, which developed gradually, was caused by repeated 
  exposure to high humidity and dust on the job and was therefore compensable 
  as an injury by accident.Â  Similarly, in Stokes, supra, we found 
  a psychological disorder which developed over a period of months compensable 
  as an injury by accident.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  . . . .
Here, it is uncontested that Claimantâ€™s carpal tunnel syndrome 
  was caused by her work activities.Â  The lack of a definite time of injury is 
  therefore not dispositive.

Pee, 352 S.C. at 170-72, 573 S.E.2d at 787-88 
  (footnote omitted).Â  Whether Hargrove could identify a precipitating event is 
  irrelevant in determining if she is entitled to benefits.
Perdue maintains Hargrove exonerated the company 
  when she stated that nothing unusual happened to her arm while she was working 
  there and that she never experienced pain and swelling in her hand after working 
  at Perdue.Â  Yet, this testimony does not provide a full account of the evidence 
  presented on the issue.Â  Hargrove testified that on March 23, 2000, after working 
  a full shift at Perdue, she went to her second-shift job at Dillon Yarn.Â  She 
  declared that after she clocked in, but before beginning her shift, she began 
  experiencing a funny feeling in the fingers of her left hand.Â Â Â  Furthermore, 
  her supervisor at Dillon Yarn professed Hargrove never complained about experiencing 
  problems with her arms or hands prior to her beginning the job at Perdue.Â  Thus, 
  the evidence clearly shows Hargrove had problems with her left hand and arm 
  after working at Perdue.
Perdue gives credence to the fact that Hargrove 
  did not work full time her first two weeks at Perdue.Â  Hargrove worked 25.61 
  hours her first week at Perdue and 23.18 hours the second week.Â  Although the 
  entire first day consisted of classroom training, for the remainder of her days 
  the first week, Hargrove spent four hours in class and four hours performing 
  her normal job, which consisted of pulling the skin off of chickens and removing 
  their entrails.Â  Hargrove testified she spent the majority of her time the second 
  week on a regular line, which processed anywhere from 2,000 to 5,000 chickens 
  per day.Â  Furthermore, Dr. Jacobus concluded Hargroveâ€™s â€œlong-term repetitious 
  activitiesâ€ at Dillon Yarn caused the carpal tunnel syndrome and her job at 
  Perdue â€œpossibly . . . exacerbate[d]â€ the problems.Â  Concomitantly, there is 
  substantial evidence in the record that Hargroveâ€™s activities while working 
  for Perdue exacerbated her condition.
II.Â  Dr. Jacobus
After providing a summary of the evidence presented, 
  the Single Commissioner made specific findings of fact, including that Hargroveâ€™s 
  employment with Dillon Yarn caused her carpal tunnel syndrome and her employment 
  with Perdue exacerbated the condition.Â  Perdue avers the Single Commissioner 
  misinterpreted Dr. Jacobusâ€™ testimony.Â  Specifically, Perdue asserts the Single 
  Commissioner erred when she noted in her order that Dr. Jacobus â€œstated that 
  both jobs would have exacerbated her problem.â€
The disputed testimony arose as a result of a hypothetical 
  question posed by Hargroveâ€™s attorney.Â  The question followed the chain of events 
  in Hargroveâ€™s case, but inaccurately suggested Hargrove spent one entire week 
  in orientation followed by two weeks of performing her normal job.Â  The attorney 
  then asked Dr. Jacobus if he had an opinion as to which job would most likely 
  be the cause of Hargroveâ€™s problem.Â  Dr. Jacobus responded:

It would therefore be my opinion that the long-term repetitious 
  activities, as I believe you related with her first job activities would have 
  been the activities that instituted the changes leading to the diagnosis or 
  at least the symptoms of carpal tunnel syndrome.Â  The secondary job responsibilities 
  of stripping chicken skin, as I perceive that to be, would therefore possibly 
  exacerbateâ€”exacerbate the symptoms that were instituted by the initial employee 
  responsibilities.

This was not the first or only time Dr. Jacobus indicated 
  he considered Hargroveâ€™s injuries to be work-related.Â  In a letter dated January 
  18, 2001, Dr. Jacobus stated: â€œIt would be my opinion that the symptoms related 
  to the left upper extremity were most probably caused and aggravated by repetitive 
  activities related to her work.â€
Expert medical testimony is designed to aid the Appellate 
  Panel in coming to the correct conclusion.Â  Sharpe v. Case Produce, Inc., 
  336 S.C. 154, 519 S.E.2d 102 (1999); Tiller v. National Health Care Ctr., 
  334 S.C. 333, 513 S.E.2d 843 (1999).Â  Therefore, the Appellate Panel determines 
  the weight and credit to be given to the expert testimony.Â  Tiller, 334 
  S.C. at 340, 513 S.E.2d at 846; Corbin v. Kohler Co., 351 S.C. 613, 571 
  S.E.2d 92 (Ct. App. 2002).Â  Once admitted, expert testimony is to be considered 
  just like any other testimony.Â  Tiller, 334 S.C. at 340, 513 S.E.2d at 
  846; Corbin, 351 S.C. at 624, 571 S.E.2d at 98.
â€œIf a medical expert is unwilling to state with certainty 
  a connection between an accident and an injury, the â€˜expression of a cautious 
  opinionâ€™ may support an award if there are facts outside the medical testimony 
  that also support an award.â€Â  Tiller, 334 S.C. at 340, 513 S.E.2d at 
  846.Â  Thus, if medical expert testimony is not solely relied upon to establish 
  causation, the fact finder must look to the facts and circumstances of the case.Â  
  Id. at 341, 513 S.E.2d at 846.Â  Proof that a claimant sustained an injury 
  may be established by circumstantial and direct evidence where circumstances 
  lead an unprejudiced mind to reasonably infer the injury was caused by the accident.Â  
  Id. at 341, 513 S.E.2d at 846-47.Â  However, such evidence need not reach 
  such a degree of certainty as to exclude every reasonable or possible conclusion 
  other than that reached by the Commission.Â  Id. at 341, 513 S.E.2d at 
  847.
Although medical testimony is entitled to great respect, 
  the fact finder may disregard it if there is other competent evidence in the 
  record.Â  See Tiller, 334 S.C. at 340, 513 S.E.2d at 846 (stating 
  that medical testimony should not be held conclusive irrespective of other evidence).Â  
  In deciding whether substantial evidence supports a finding of causation, it 
  is appropriate to consider both the lay and expert evidence.Â  Sharpe, 
  336 S.C. at 161, 519 S.E.2d at 106.
Neither the Single Commissioner nor the Appellate 
  Panel erred in relying on the testimony of Dr. Jacobus.Â  The subtle differences 
  posed in the hypothetical question, compared to the actual events, merely affect 
  the weight of the doctorâ€™s testimony and not its validity.
III.Â  Aggravation 
  of Pre-Existing Condition
Perdue asserts â€œDr. Jacobus said nothing about 
  any permanent injury being caused by her employment at Perdue.Â  He only speculated 
  about an aggravation of symptoms.â€
A work-related accident which aggravates 
  or accelerates a pre-existing condition, infirmity, or disease is compensable.Â  
  Brown v. R.L. Jordan Oil Co., 291 S.C. 272, 353 S.E.2d 280 (1987); Sturkie 
  v. Ballenger Corp., 268 S.C. 536, 235 S.E.2d 120 (1977); Mullinax v. 
  Winn-Dixie Stores, Inc., 318 S.C. 431, 458 S.E.2d 76 (Ct. App. 1995).Â  A 
  condition is compensable unless it is due solely to the natural progression 
  of a pre-existing condition.Â  Mullinax, 318 S.C. at 437, 458 S.E.2d at 
  80.Â  It is no defense that the accident, standing alone, would not have caused 
  the claimantâ€™s condition, because the employer takes the employee as it finds 
  him or her.Â  Id.Â  â€œ[A]ggravation of a pre-existing condition is compensable 
  where disability is continued for a longer time, even though no disability would 
  normally have resulted from the injury alone, or even if the aggravation would 
  have caused no injury to an employee who was not afflicted with the condition.â€Â  
  Id. (internal quotations omitted).
When a pre-existing condition or disease is accelerated 
  or aggravated by injury or accident â€œarising out of and in the course of the 
  employment,â€ the resulting disability is a compensable injury.Â  Brown, 
  291 S.C. at 275, 353 S.E.2d at 282; Arnold v. Benjamin Booth Co., 257 
  S.C. 337, 185 S.E.2d 830 (1971); see also Sturkie, 268 S.C. at 
  541, 235 S.E.2d at 122 (exacerbation of pre-existing disease or injury arising 
  out of or in course of employment is compensable).
The right of a claimant to compensation for aggravation 
  of a pre-existing condition arises only where there is a dormant condition which 
  has produced no disability but which becomes disabling by reason of the aggravating 
  injury.Â  Hines v. Pacific Mills, 214 S.C. 125, 51 S.E.2d 383 (1949).Â  
  A determination of whether a claimantâ€™s condition was accelerated or aggravated 
  by an accidental injury is a factual matter for the Appellate Panel.Â  Brown, 
  291 S.C. at 275, 353 S.E.2d at 282.Â  Where there is a conflict in the evidence 
  from the same or different witnesses, the Panelâ€™s findings of fact may not be 
  set aside.Â  Id.
IV.Â  Substantial 
  Evidence to Support Decision of Appellate Panel
After thoroughly reviewing the record, we find 
  substantial evidence supports the Appellate Panelâ€™s ruling.Â  Hargroveâ€™s supervisor 
  at Dillon Yarn testified Hargrove never complained about problems with her hand 
  or arm prior to beginning her employment with Perdue.Â  Although Hargrove experienced 
  problems with her hand and arm before working at Perdue, she said she would 
  go home after work and soak her hand and arm and then â€œit would be all rightâ€â€”â€œ[t]he 
  pain would go awayâ€ and the â€œswelling would go down.â€
 On March 1, 2000, Hargrove applied for her position 
  at Perdue.Â  At that time, she was given a physical specifically designed for 
  the rigors of the job for which she was applying.Â  Several of the tests were 
  aimed at detecting problems with her arms and/or hands.Â  Nurse Sutherland testified 
  Hargrove passed all the tests with no problems and possessed a strong grip in 
  both hands.
On March 16, 2000, after completing her shift at 
  Perdue, Hargrove complained to her supervisor at Dillon Yarn for the first time 
  that her hand and arm were giving her problems.Â  On March 23, 2000, Hargrove 
  finished her shift at Perdue and was clocking in at Dillon Yarn when she noticed 
  a funny feeling in the fingers on her left hand.Â  At the time this â€œfunny feelingâ€ 
  began, Hargrove had not yet started her work duties for the day at Dillon Yarn.Â  
  Later that night, Hargroveâ€™s arm became swollen and she asked if she could be 
  excused to go see a doctor.
On March 27, 2000, Hargrove was sent to Dr. Wallace, 
  who opined that he did not â€œthink she [could] physically handle both [jobs].â€Â  
  Dr. Wallace referred Hargrove to Dr. Jacobus, who expressed the opinion that 
  her condition was indeed work-related.
In deciding whether substantial evidence exists, it is appropriate 
  to consider both the lay and expert evidence.Â  See Sharpe v. Case 
  Produce, Inc., 336 S.C. 154, 519 S.E.2d 102 (1999).Â  Although there is evidence 
  from which the Appellate Panel could have gone the other way, there is clearly 
  evidence which would allow reasonable minds to reach the conclusion the Panel 
  reached.Â  Substantial evidence supports the Appellate Panelâ€™s finding that Hargroveâ€™s 
  work at Perdue aggravated or exacerbated her pre-existing condition.
CONCLUSION
We find substantial evidence supports the 
  Appellate Panelâ€™s order.Â  The Circuit Court did not err in affirming this decision.Â  
  Accordingly, the Circuit Courtâ€™s ruling is
AFFIRMED.
 HUFF, J., concurs.
KITTREDGE, J., dissents in a separate opinion.
KITTREDGE, J.:Â  I respectfully dissent.Â  
  This appeal presents the question of whether substantial evidence supports the 
  Commissionâ€™s finding that Sandra Hargroveâ€™s nine-day tenure at Perdue Farms 
  â€“ comprised entirely of orientation, training and light work â€“ exacerbated a 
  condition caused by her long-time employment at Dillon Yarn.Â  Having carefully 
  considered the record and applicable standard of review, I would reverse based 
  on my conclusion that the Commissionâ€™s finding that Hargrove aggravated her 
  pre-existing condition in the course of her brief employment at Perdue Farms 
  is not supported by substantial evidence.Â  In my judgment, the Commissionâ€™s 
  decision rests solely on speculation.
Hargroveâ€™s condition undisputedly 
  originated from her work at Dillon Yarn, where she was employed periodically 
  from 1992 through March 23, 2000.Â  Neither Hargrove nor Dillon Yarn dispute 
  the Commissionâ€™s finding that Hargroveâ€™s condition was caused by her employment 
  with Dillon Yarn.Â  Thus, this finding is the law of the case.Â  See 
  Unisun Ins. v. Hawkins, 342 S.C. 537, 544, 537 S.E.2d 559, 563 (Ct. 
  App. 2000) (stating an unappealed ruling is the law of the case which the appellate 
  court must assume was correct).Â  Hargrove worked eight-hour shifts at Dillon 
  Yarn, during which she would lift, bag, and box between 600 and 800 spools of 
  yarn from a texturing machine.
On March 13, 2000, Hargrove began her brief tenure 
  with Perdue Farms, while continuing to work full-time at Dillon Yarn.Â  Hargrove 
  worked only 25.61 hours in her first of two weeks as an employee of Perdue Farms.Â  
  Her first day of employment at Perdue Farms was entirely devoted to orientation 
  and classroom training.Â  On the remaining four days of her first week, Hargrove 
  spent four hours each day receiving additional classroom training and four hours 
  each day on a special production line used to train new employees.Â  The training 
  line moved at half the speed of the normal production lines.Â  Hargrove would 
  rotate between functions throughout the day rather than doing one thing repetitively 
  all day.Â  According to Hargrove, the work using her hands did not involve â€œany 
  real effort.â€
During Hargroveâ€™s second week at Perdue Farms, 
  she worked 23.18 hours over a four-day period.Â  She continued to work at a training 
  line until fourth day, March 23, 2000, when the line went down.Â  Although she 
  â€œdidnâ€™t do much that dayâ€ at Perdue Farms, Hargrove did help move empty boxes.Â  
  Later that same day, Hargrove went to her job at Dillon Yarn, where she complained 
  to her supervisor that her left hand was â€œswollen,â€ â€œfeeling funny,â€ and had 
  â€œstarted hurting.â€Â  The supervisor sent her to the plantâ€™s nurse, who gave Hargrove 
  Tylenol.Â  Hargrove completed her shift, but later went to a physician for additional 
  treatment.Â  Upon the physicianâ€™s recommendation,Â  Hargrove did not return to 
  work at Dillon Yarn or Perdue Farms.Â  She later brought the present action, 
  seeking workersâ€™ compensation benefits from Dillon Yarn.Â  Dillon Yarn joined 
  Perdue Farms as a defendant.Â  
In deposition testimony, the following exchange 
  occurred between Dillon Yarnâ€™s counsel and Hargrove:

[Counsel]:Â  Did the fingers on your left hand feel funny 
  while you were working at Perdue [on March 23, 2000]?
[Hargrove]:  No sir.

When Dillon Yarnâ€™s counsel asked Hargrove whether 
  she had â€œever felt that funny feeling before,â€ Hargrove responded, â€œThe only 
  time I felt that is like when I worked hard at Dillon Yarn.â€Â  When questioned 
  as to whether she had any knowledge of an incident or accident at Perdue Farms 
  related to her condition, she responded, â€œNo, sir.â€
Dr. Dwight Jacobus, a general orthopedic 
  surgeon who served as one of Hargroveâ€™s treating physicians, provided additional 
  deposition testimony.Â  During the deposition, a hypothetical question posed 
  to Dr. Jacobus solicited his opinion regarding which of Hargroveâ€™s jobs had 
  caused her condition, or whether the condition was caused by â€œa combination 
  of the twoâ€ jobs.Â  In pertinent part, the hypothetical was premised on the false 
  assumption that Hargroveâ€™s employment at Perdue Farms consisted of â€œone week 
  of training and two weeks of actually performing the job.â€Â  Jacobus opined that 
  the long-term, repetitive nature of her job at Dillon Yarn â€œwould have been 
  the activities that instituted the changes leading to the diagnosis or at least 
  the symptoms of carpal tunnel syndrome.â€Â  He added that the â€œsecondary job responsibilities 
  of stripping chicken [at Perdue Farms], as I perceive that to be, would therefore 
  possibly exacerbate â€¦ symptoms that were instituted by the initial responsibilities 
  [at Dillon Yarn.]â€Â  (emphasis added).
The order of the single commissioner erroneously 
  stated that Dr. Jacobus opined that Hargroveâ€™s â€œleft upper extremity problems 
  were most probably caused and aggravated by her work â€¦ [and] â€¦ both jobs 
  would have exacerbated her problem.â€Â  (emphasis added).Â  The commissioner concluded 
  that Hargroveâ€™s work at Perdue exacerbated her pre-existing condition.Â  Consequently, 
  the commissioner ordered Dillon Yarn and Perdue Farms to each pay one-half of 
  the temporary total disability benefits awarded Hargrove, as well as charges 
  for all past, present, and continuing medical expenses related to the injury.Â  
  An appellate panel of the Commission affirmed, adopting all of the single commissionerâ€™s 
  findings.Â  The circuit court affirmed the Commission.
I recognize that in workersâ€™ compensation cases, 
  compensation may be awarded although â€œa medical expert is unwilling to state 
  with certainty a connection between an accident and an injury â€¦ â€˜if there are 
  facts outside the medical testimony that also support an award.â€™â€Â  Tiller 
  v. Natâ€™l Health Care Ctr., 334 S.C. 333, 340, 513 S.E.2d 843, 846 (1999), 
  citing Grice v. Dickerson, Inc., 241 S.C. 225, 127 S.E.2d 722 (1962).Â  
  This court applied this principle in Muir v. C.R. Bard, Inc., 336 S.C. 
  266, 287, 519 S.E.2d 583, 594 (Ct. App. 1999) (â€œIf a medical expert is unwilling 
  to state with certainty a connection between an accident and an injury, the 
  â€˜expression of a cautious opinionâ€™ may support an award if there are facts outside 
  the medical testimony that also support an awardâ€).Â  Here, the Commission relied 
  solely on the testimony of Dr. Jacobus in finding that Hargroveâ€™s employment 
  at Perdue Farms exacerbated her condition.Â  The Commission adopted the single 
  commissionerâ€™s finding that Dr. Jacobus opined that Hargroveâ€™s condition was 
  â€œmost probablyâ€ exacerbated by both of her jobs.Â  Dr. Jacobus rendered no such 
  opinion, as he only testified that Hargroveâ€™s work at Perdue Farms â€œpossibly 
  exacerbate[d]â€ symptoms of the condition caused by her work at Dillon Yarn.Â  
  At best, Dr. Jacobus provided an â€œexpression of a cautious opinionâ€ with respect 
  to the relationship between Hargroveâ€™s condition and her work at Perdue Farms.Â  
  There is no additional evidence, lay or otherwise, supporting an award against 
  Perdue Farms.Â  In fact, Hargroveâ€™s testimony refutes any suggestion or inference 
  of a connection between her injury and her nine-day employment at Perdue Farms, 
  which she conceded did not involve â€œany real effort.â€Â  â€œWorkersâ€™ compensation 
  awards must not be based on surmise, conjecture or speculation.â€ Tiller, 
  334 S.C. at 339, 513 S.E.2d at 845.Â  
I reach this conclusion fully cognizant of the 
  deferential substantial evidence standard of review applicable to appeals from 
  the Commission.Â  Consistent with this deferential standard of review, an appellate 
  court must nevertheless ensure the record contains some evidence beyond a mere 
  scintilla which, considering the record as a whole, would allow reasonable minds 
  to concur in the conclusion reached by the Commission.Â  See Lark v. 
  Bi-Lo, Inc., 276 S.C. 130, 135, 276 S.E.2d 304, 306 (1981) (holding that 
  an appellate courtâ€™s review of appeals from the Commission is limited to deciding 
  whether the Commissionâ€™s decision is unsupported by substantial evidence or 
  is controlled by some error of law);Â  Broughton v. South of the Border, 
  336 S.C. 488, 496, 520 S.E.2d 634, 637 (Ct. App. 1999) (â€œSubstantial evidence 
  is not a mere scintilla of evidence, nor the evidence viewed blindly from one 
  side of the case, but is evidence which, considering the record as a whole, 
  would allow reasonable minds to reach the conclusion the administrative agency 
  reached in order to justify its actionâ€).Â  Mindful of this deferential standard 
  of review, the record in my judgment yields, at best, a mere scintilla of evidence 
  to support the Commissionâ€™s finding that Hargrove aggravated her pre-existing 
  condition in the course of her brief employment at Perdue Farms.Â  I would reverse.

 
   
    [1]  Hargrove testified she was seeking a first shift job that would enable 
    her to go back to school in the evenings.Â  However, she was working both jobs 
    when the problems underlying this appeal occurred. 

 
   
    [2]  Dr. Wallace is the company doctor for both Perdue and Dillon Yarn.

 
   
    [3]  Hargrove did not return to work for either employer following her 
    first visit with Dr. Wallace.

 
   
    [4]  Dillon Yarn did not appeal this final order and, in fact, participates 
    in this appeal as a Respondent.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
  In The Court of Appeals

 
   
     
      
        Timothy R. Sponar, Respondent,
      
    
  

v.
 
   
     
      
        South Carolina Department of Public Safety, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Charleston County
  Â John M. Milling, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 3847
  Submitted May 12, 2004 â€“ Filed July 19, 2004

REVERSED

 
   
     
      
        C. Cliff Rollins, of Blythewood, and Frank L. Valenta, Jr., of Columbia, 
          for Appellant.
        Stephan Victor Futeral, of Mt. Pleasant, for Respondent.
      
    
  

HUFF, J.:Â  Following his arrest for driving under the influence, Timothy 
  R. Sponar refused to take a Datamaster test.Â  Pursuant to this refusal, the 
  Department of Public Safety (DPS) revoked Sponarâ€™s driverâ€™s license.Â  Sponar 
  requested an implied consent hearing, after which a DPS Administrative Hearing 
  Officer upheld the suspension.Â  Sponar then appealed this decision to the circuit 
  court, which reversed the suspension.Â  DPS now appeals arguing the circuit court 
  erred by (1) improperly applying the standard of review to reverse the hearing 
  officerâ€™s decision and (2) considering Sponarâ€™s state of mind at the time he 
  refused to take the Datamaster test.Â  We reverse and reinstate the suspension.Â  

FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND 
On August 7, 2000, Officer C. Googe of the Mount Pleasant Police Department 
  observed a vehicle traveling at 78 miles per hour in a 55 mile per hour zone 
  and initiated a traffic stop.Â  During the stop, Officer Googe noticed the driver, 
  Sponar, smelled of alcohol and had glassy, bloodshot eyes and slurred speech.Â  

Accordingly, the officer asked Sponar to exit the vehicle and complete a number 
  of field sobriety tests.Â  As Sponar could not properly perform any of the tests, 
  the officer placed him under arrest, advised him of his Miranda [1]  rights, and transported him to the Mount 
  Pleasant Police Department where he then turned Sponar over to Officer Whitcomb 
  for administration of a Datamaster test. 
  [2] Â  
Upon arrival at the police station, Officer Googe turned Sponar over to Officer 
  Whitcomb so that he could administer the Datamaster test to determine if Sponarâ€™s 
  blood alcohol level was within the legal limit.Â  Officer Whitcomb explained 
  to Sponar his Miranda rights and then advised him of his implied consent 
  rights, reading them verbatim from the advisement form provided by SLED and 
  providing him with a copy.Â  
During a mandatory twenty-minute waiting period 
  prior to administering the test, Sponar initiated conversation with the officer.Â  
  Sponar repeatedly asked whether he should take the test or whether he should 
  refuse, and asked the consequences of taking or refusing the test.Â  Officer 
  Whitcomb responded it was not his decision to make and that Respondent would 
  have to decide on his own.Â  Sponar asked whether he would still go to jail if 
  he took the test, and the officer replied that it did not matter if he took 
  the test or not, because he would be going to jail either way.Â  Thereafter, 
  Respondent refused to take the test.Â  
Pursuant to this refusal, Officer Whitcomb completed 
  a Notice of Suspension, and Sponarâ€™s driving privileges were suspended.Â  Sponar 
  requested an implied consent hearing and appealed the suspension of his driving 
  privileges to DPSâ€™s Office of Administrative Hearings.Â  Sponar argued at the 
  hearing that Officer Whitcombâ€™s statement â€“ he would go to jail whether he took 
  the test or not â€“ had the effect of distorting his implied consent rights.Â  
  He contended, because his implied consent rights were not properly given, the 
  suspension should be reversed.Â  On March 12, 2001, the administrative hearing 
  officer issued an order sustaining the suspension.Â  She noted the officer had 
  read Sponar his rights verbatim, Sponar indicated he understood his rights, 
  and it was only after that, while waiting during the observation period, that 
  Sponar began questioning the officer about what would happen to him and Officer 
  Whitcomb responded he would be taken to jail as part of their procedure whether 
  he submitted to the test or not.Â  
Respondent then appealed the hearing officerâ€™s ruling 
  to the circuit court, which issued an order reversing the decision of the hearing 
  officer.Â  The circuit court judge noted, pursuant to S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 1-23-380(a)(6), 
  the court may reverse the decision of the administrative agency â€œif substantial 
  rights of the Petitioner have been prejudiced for various reasons, including 
  violations of constitutional or statutory provisions, errors of law, or arbitrariness 
  or capriciousness.â€ He determined, because Â§ 56-5-2950(b)(1) of the South Carolina 
  Code provides in pertinent part that if the alcohol level at the time of testing 
  is â€œfive one-hundredths of one percent or less, it is conclusively presumed 
  that the person was not under the influence of alcohol,â€ there was no legal 
  basis to support the officerâ€™s statement to Sponar that he â€œwas to be jailed 
  â€˜by lawâ€™ regardless of his decision to submit to the breath test.â€Â  S.C. Code 
  Ann. Â§ 56-5-2950(b)(1) (Supp. 2003).Â  He reasoned that if Sponar fell within 
  this provision, the officer would have lacked probable cause to detain him for 
  driving under the influence.Â  Accordingly, the circuit court judge found the 
  officerâ€™s instructions were erroneous and unlawfully suggested Sponarâ€™s decision 
  to submit to the breath test â€œwould largely be in vain.â€Â  DPS argues this ruling 
  was in error.Â  We agree.
STANDARD 
  OF REVIEW
Appeals from administrative agencies are governed by the Administrative 
Procedures Act (APA).Â  Byerly Hosp. v. South Carolina State Health & Human 
Servs. Fin. Commâ€™n, 319 S.C. 225, 229, 460 S.E.2d 383, 385 (1995).Â  The standard 
the circuit court uses to review such decisions is provided by section 1-23-380(6): 
 
  The court shall not substitute its judgment for that of the agency as to 
    the weight of the evidence on questions of fact.Â  The court may affirm the 
    decision of the agency or remand the case for further proceedings.Â  The court 
    may reverse or modify the decision if substantial rights of the appellant 
    have been prejudiced because the administrative findings, inferences, conclusions 
    or decisions are:
   (a)  in violation of constitutional or statutory provisions;
    (b) in excess of the statutory authority of the agency;
    (c)  made upon unlawful procedure;
    (d) affected by other error of law;
    (e)  clearly erroneous in view of the reliable, probative and substantial 
    evidence on the whole record; or
    (f)   arbitrary or capricious or characterized by abuse of discretion 
    or clearly unwarranted exercise of discretion.

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 1-23-380(A)(6) (Supp. 2003).Â  In reviewing a final decision 
  of an administrative agency, the circuit court essentially sits as an appellate 
  court to review alleged errors committed by the agency.Â  Kiawah Resort Assocs. 
  v. South Carolina Tax Commâ€™n, 318 S.C. 502, 505, 458 S.E.2d 542, 544 (1995).Â  
  An abuse of discretion occurs when a decision is controlled by an error of law 
  or is without evidentiary support.Â  Mictronics v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of 
  Revenue, 345 S.C. 506, 510, 548 S.E.2d 223, 225 (Ct. App. 2001).Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS 
DPS argues the circuit court improperly applied the standard of review under 
  the APA in reversing the decision of the administrative hearing officer.Â  We 
  agree.

  The license to operate a motor vehicle upon the public highways of this state 
    is not a property right, but is a mere privilege subject to reasonable regulations 
    under the police power in the interest of the public safety and welfare.Â  
    Such privilege is always subject to revocation or suspension for any cause 
    relating to public safety.Â  However, the privilege cannot be revoked arbitrarily 
    or capriciously.

Summersell v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Pub. Safety, 
  334 S.C. 357, 366, 513 S.E.2d 619, 624 (Ct. App. 1999) (citations omitted), 
  vacated in part on other grounds, 337 S.C. 19, 522 S.E.2d 144 (1999). 
  
At the hearing before the circuit court, Sponarâ€™s 
  attorney argued that Sponar was improperly given his implied consent rights 
  such that he was coerced into not taking the breath test.Â  He asserted, had 
  Sponar taken the test and obtained a reading below .05%, the police would have 
  had no basis to continue his incarceration.Â  Thus, he contended, because Sponar 
  was told he was going to jail regardless of whether he submitted to the test, 
  Sponar was coerced into not taking the test.Â  The attorney for DPS countered 
  that Sponar was not coerced in any way.Â  He contended that some officers take 
  the position that once an individual is arrested for DUI, that person is already 
  under arrest and cannot be â€œun-arrest[ed].â€Â  Thus, this officer merely told 
  Sponar the â€œtruthâ€ about the policy they followed.Â  
In reversing the suspension, the circuit court determined 
  there was no legal basis to support the officerâ€™s statement to Sponar that he 
  â€œwas to be jailed â€˜by lawâ€™ regardless of his decision to submit to the breath 
  test.â€Â  It relied on our Supreme Courtâ€™s opinion in Town of Mount Pleasant 
  v. Shaw, 315 S.C. 111, 432 S.E.2d 450 (1993) in finding the implied consent 
  instructions given to Sponar were erroneous.Â  In that case, Shaw was arrested 
  and charged with DUI.Â  Prior to administration of a breath test, Shaw was informed 
  that if he did not take the test, his privilege to drive in South Carolina would 
  be suspended for a ninety-day period.Â  Shaw took the test, registering a .25% 
  blood alcohol reading.Â  Shaw appealed his subsequent magistrate court conviction 
  and the circuit court reversed holding the implied consent advisory did not 
  adequately inform him of his option to refuse the test.Â  The Supreme Court reversed 
  the circuit court and reinstated Shawâ€™s conviction.Â  In doing so, the court 
  noted a common sense reading of the advisory given to Shaw made clear the consequences 
  of both taking the test and refusing to take the test.Â  Id. at 113, 432 
  S.E.2d at 451.Â  The court went on to adopt the following rule:

  [I]f the arrested person is reasonably informed of his rights, duties 
    and obligations under our implied consent law and he is neither tricked 
    nor misled into thinking he has no right to refuse the test to determine 
    the alcohol content in his blood, urine or breath, the test will generally 
    be held admissible.

Id. at 113, 432 S.E.2d at 451 (emphasis in 
  original) (citation omitted).
Shortly after the Shaw decision, our Supreme Court addressed the sufficiency 
  of an implied consent advisory following the suspension of the driverâ€™s license 
  of an individual who refused a breathalyzer test after his arrest for DUI.Â  
  In Percy v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Highways and Pub. Transp., 315 S.C. 
  383, 434 S.E.2d 264 (1993), Percy, who was licensed to drive in Ohio, was advised 
  Ohio authorities would be advised of any South Carolina suspension for refusal 
  to submit to a breath test.Â  The arresting officer further advised Percy he 
  was unaware of the consequences in Ohio of a refusal to take the test in South 
  Carolina.Â  Percy refused the breathalyzer, resulting in a ninety-day suspension 
  in South Carolina and a one-year suspension in Ohio.Â  Percy had his South Carolina 
  suspension reversed by the circuit court, based on his assertion that the implied 
  consent warning was insufficient in that it did not contain information that 
  Ohio would honor the South Carolina suspension.Â  Our Supreme Court reversed 
  and reinstated Percyâ€™s suspension, stating â€œ[t]he statute requires only that 
  an accused be advised that his privilege to drive will be suspended for 90 days 
  if he refuses the breathalyzer.â€Â  Id. at 385, 434 S.E.2d at 265.Â  Noting 
  the courtâ€™s recent recognition in Shaw that an implied consent advisory 
  is sufficient if the defendant is reasonably informed of his rights and is neither 
  tricked nor misled into thinking he has no right to refuse the test, the court 
  determined it would be unreasonable to require law enforcement to advise out-of-state 
  motorists of the consequences that refusal to take the test will have in their 
  respective states.Â  Accordingly, the court found Percy was adequately advised 
  pursuant to the implied consent statute.Â  Id. at 385, 434 S.E.2d at 265-66. 

We find the officerâ€™s statement to Sponar that 
  he would be going to jail regardless of his decision on whether to submit to 
  the breath test did not inadequately advise Sponar pursuant to the implied consent 
  statute.Â  First, Â§ 56-5-2950(b)(1) provides that one is conclusively presumed 
  to not be under the influence of alcohol if his or her breath test registers 
  .05% or lower.Â  Such a result does not rule out the possibility that the individual 
  is under the influence of some other intoxicant, or a combination of alcohol 
  and another intoxicant.Â  Indeed, an individual may fail field sobriety tests 
  and/or exhibit other signs of being under the influence of an intoxicant regardless 
  of whether the individual does not have enough alcohol in his or her system 
  to register as being under the influence of alcohol.
Second, the evidence of record shows the officers, 
  as a matter of policy, often do not release an individual, regardless of whether 
  the breath test results show an individual is conclusively presumed to not be 
  under the influence of alcohol.Â  Even if we assumed for the sake of argument 
  that it is improper for authorities to continue to detain an individual after 
  they have registered below a .05% on a breath test, this is irrelevant to an 
  individualâ€™s decision on whether to submit to a breath test. 
  [3] Â  Officer Whitcombâ€™s statement to Sponar in this regard was simply a 
  truthful explanation of what would happen to him next, and it is irrelevant 
  as to whether continued detention in such a situation would be lawful. 
Finally, the statements made by Officer Whitcomb 
  to SponarÂ  did not â€œtrick or misleadâ€ Sponar into refusing the breath test.Â  
  Such a statement indicated that his decision, either way, would be of no consequence 
  to his subsequent immediate incarceration.Â  Officer Whitcomb explicitly indicated 
  to Sponar that his decision on whether to take the breath test would have no 
  impact on whether he would be jailed.Â  Indeed, the only statement made by the 
  officer to Sponar that could reasonably be said to have affected Sponarâ€™s decision 
  on whether or not to take the breath test was that his license would be suspended 
  for a ninety-day period if he refused the test.Â  The authorities are required 
  by law to inform an individual of this consequence before they may administer 
  such a test. [4] Â  A common sense 
  reading of the advisory given to Sponar made clear the consequences of 
  both taking the test and refusing to take the test.Â  He was reasonably informed 
  of his rights, duties and obligations, and was not tricked or misled into thinking 
  he had no right to refuse the test.Â  Shaw, 315 S.C. at 113, 432 S.E.2d 
  at 451.Â  Neither was he tricked or misled into refusing the test.
Because we reverse the trial courtâ€™s decision on 
  this ground, DPSâ€™s remaining argument need not be addressed.Â  See Futch 
  v. McAllister Towing of Georgetown, Inc., 335 S.C. 598, 613, 518 S.E.2d 
  591, 598 (1999) (appellate court need not address remaining issues when disposition 
  of prior issue is dispositive). 
Accordingly, the circuit courtâ€™s decision is reversed and the suspension is 
  reinstated. 
REVERSED.
ANDERSON and KITTREDGE, JJ., concur.


 
   [1] Miranda 
    v. Arizona, 384 U.S. 436, 86 S. Ct. 1602 (1966).

 
   
    [2] Officer Googe testified Respondent told him he had â€œa couple of drinksâ€ 
    at a place called Hanahanâ€™s.Â  In addition, after the officer found a six-pack 
    with only one beverage remaining, Sponar admitted to consuming the other five.Â  
  

 
   [3] As 
    noted by Sponarâ€™s attorney in argument before the circuit court, if the authorities 
    continued to incarcerate an individual for DUI under such circumstances, that 
    individualâ€™s recourse may be a civil action for false imprisonment or false 
    arrest.Â  

 
   [4] See 
    S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 56-5-2950(a)(1) (Supp. 2003) (â€œNo tests may be administered 
    or samples obtained unless the person has been informed in writing that: (1) 
    he does not have to take the test or give the samples, but that his privilege 
    to drive must be suspended or denied for at least ninety days if he refuses 
    to submit to the tests and that his refusal may be used against him in court.â€).

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
  In The Court of Appeals
 
   
     
      
        Diane Steffenson, Appellant,
      
    
  

v.
 
   
     
      
        David A. Olsen, Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Greenwood County
  Â Billy A. Tunstall, Jr., Family Court Judge

Opinion No. 3848
  Heard May 12, 2004 â€“ Filed July 19, 2004

AFFIRMED IN PART AND REVERSED IN PART

 
   
     
      
        John M. Gulledge, of Troy, for Appellant.
        C. Rauch Wise, of Greenwood, for Respondent.
      
    
  

STILWELL, J.:Â  In this domestic relations 
  action, we must decide whether the trial court erred in (1) interpreting a foreign 
  courtâ€™s award of retirement benefits to include only those benefits accrued 
  at the time of the divorce and (2) offsetting the award of retirement benefits 
  by the amount of overpaid child support.Â  We affirm in part and reverse in part.
BACKGROUND 
David Olsen (Husband) and Diane Steffenson (Wife) 
  divorced in 1984 in Japan, where Husband was stationed while in the Air Force.Â  
  They divorced under Japanese proceedings of conciliation.Â  The Japanese order 
  granted Wife custody of the partiesâ€™ two children and required Husband to pay 
  child support of $250 per month for each child, with support for each child 
  terminating when that child reached 18.Â  Additionally, the order provided:

  4.Â  [Husband] shall pay [Wife] the amount equal to 15% of the amount of retirement 
    pay, which will be paid to [Husband] at his retirement.

Other than the allocation of retirement pay, the 
  order did not provide for alimony or the distribution of marital property.Â  
  Wifeâ€™s attorney represented to the trial court that the Japanese family court 
  does not award alimony, and Wife testified the Japanese family court instructed 
  the parties to divide their real and personal property themselves.Â  
Pursuant to military regulations, the Japanese court order was transmitted 
  to an office that automatically deducted the child support payments from Husbandâ€™s 
  pay and forwarded them to Wife. Â The deductions and payments were automatically 
  reduced when the oldest child reached 18, but the department failed to discontinue 
  deductions or payments when the youngest child reached 18.Â  The $250 monthly 
  payments continued for an additional 25 months.Â  As a result, Husband paid $6250 
  in child support after the youngest child reached majority.Â  
Husband retired and began receiving retirement pay in 2000. Â Wife brought 
  this action in South Carolina to enforce the Japanese court order after a dispute 
  arose regarding payment of retirement benefits.Â  In her complaint, Wife asserted 
  the Japanese conciliation procedure requires parties to submit a divorce agreement 
  to the court, which the court adopts and gives formal, judicial sanction equivalent 
  to a divorce decree.Â  In his responsive pleading, Husband stated he was without 
  sufficient information to form a belief regarding the nature of the conciliation 
  procedure.Â  
The court issued an initial order ruling the divorce 
  decree was entitled to recognition and enforcement.Â  Neither party appealed 
  that order.
After a hearing on the merits, the court issued an order acknowledging the 
  parties had reached an agreement that formed the Japanese courtâ€™s order, but 
  found the terms of the agreement ambiguous.Â  Upon consideration of evidence 
  outside the agreement including the testimony of the parties, the court concluded 
  the parties agreed Wife would receive only 15 percent of Husbandâ€™s retirement 
  pay that â€œaccumulated during the marriage.â€Â  The court further found and concluded 
  Husband was entitled to an offset equal to his child support overpayment.Â  
DISCUSSION 
I.Â  Retirement Benefits 
Wife argues the court erred in concluding 
  the Japanese divorce decree entitles her to only 15 percent of Husbandâ€™s retirement 
  pay that had accrued as of the date of their divorce.Â  We agree.
The trial court concluded the terms of the partiesâ€™ agreement were â€œnot clear 
  or apparent,â€ and thus considered extrinsic evidence in reaching its decision.Â  
  We, however, conclude the provision in question clearly requires Husband to 
  pay Wife 15 percent of his entire retirement benefits he receives upon retirement.Â  

â€œUnambiguous marital agreements will be enforced in accordance with their terms, 
  while ambiguous agreements will be examined in the same manner as other agreements 
  in order to determine the intention of the parties.â€Â  Lindsay v. Lindsay, 
  328 S.C. 329, 337, 491 S.E.2d 583, 587 (Ct. App. 1997).Â  Whether an ambiguity 
  exists must be determined from the language of the agreement.Â  Id.Â  If 
  an agreement is clear and unambiguous, its terms should be applied according 
  to their plain and ordinary meaning and consideration of extrinsic evidence 
  to alter that meaning is improper.Â  C.A.N. Enters. Inc. v. South Carolina 
  Health & Human Servs. Fin. Commâ€™n, 296 S.C. 373, 377-78, 373 S.E.2d 
  584, 586 (1988); see also Redwend Ltd. Pâ€™ship v. Edwards, 
  354 S.C. 459, 471, 581 S.E.2d 496, 502 (Ct. App. 2003) (â€œThe parol evidence 
  rule prevents the introduction of extrinsic evidence of agreements or understandings 
  contemporaneous with or prior to execution of a written instrument when the 
  extrinsic evidence is to be used to contradict, vary, or explain the written 
  instrument.â€).Â  
 The provision in question clearly requires Husband to pay Wife an amount equal 
  to 15 percent of his retirement pay.Â  Had the parties intended to limit the 
  award to those benefits accrued during the marriage, they could have so provided, 
  and it is not for the trial court or this court to change the terms the parties 
  agreed upon.Â  See Hardee v. Hardee, 355 S.C. 382, 387, 585 S.E.2d 
  501, 503 (2003) (â€œThe judicial function of a court of law is to enforce a contract 
  as made by the parties, and not to rewrite or to distort, under the guise of 
  judicial construction, contracts, the terms of which are plain and unambiguous.â€); 
  Charles v. Canal Ins. Co., 238 S.C. 600, 608-09, 121 S.E.2d 200, 205 
  (1961) (holding where a contractâ€™s terms are clear, the courtâ€™s function is 
  to enforce the terms and not to substitute its own judgment for that of the 
  parties).Â  
Husband agrees the retirement award provision is facially clear but contends 
  it contains a latent ambiguity that arose only when his obligation to make payments 
  began upon his retirement.Â  Because the document does not define â€œretirement 
  payâ€ or â€œamount of retirement pay,â€ Husband claims the ambiguity is whether 
  â€œamount of retirementâ€ refers to the retirement he would have been entitled 
  to had he retired at the rank he held when the parties divorced or whether it 
  was to be based on the rank he achieved by the end of his career.Â  He also argues 
  it is not clear whether Wife is entitled to a percentage of the gross pay or 
  the net disposable income.Â  Finally, Husband contends allowing Wife to receive 
  15 percent of his entire retirement benefits â€œwould give [her] the windfall 
  of an additional seventeen years of military service by [Husband].â€Â  
In essence, Husbandâ€™s argument is not that a latent 
  ambiguity is revealed upon application, but rather that he finds a literal application 
  of the provisionâ€™s terms unfair.Â  However, the courtâ€™s duty â€œis to enforce the 
  contract made by the parties regardless of its wisdom or folly, apparent unreasonableness, 
  or the partiesâ€™ failure to guard their rights carefully.â€Â  Jordan v. Sec. 
  Group, Inc., 311 S.C. 227, 230, 428 S.E.2d 705, 707 (1993).Â  Husbandâ€™s argument 
  is similar to an argument that the parties have undergone a change of circumstances.Â  
  However, just as a change of circumstances within the partiesâ€™ contemplation 
  at the time of the decree does not provide a basis for modifying a support award, 
  Husband cannot argue this agreement should be read differently because his retirement 
  benefits are more than they would have been had he retired at the rank he held 
  when the parties divorced.Â  See Eubank v. Eubank, 347 S.C. 367, 
  374, 555 S.E.2d 413, 417 (Ct. App. 2001) (holding change of circumstances within 
  the partiesâ€™ contemplation at the time of decree not a ground for altering a 
  support award).Â  In fact, the award to Wife of only 15 percent of Husbandâ€™s 
  retirement pay suggests the parties did anticipate Husband would advance in 
  rank and would be entitled to more retirement pay than that which he had accumulated 
  when the parties divorced.Â  See id.Â  (holding a court should apply 
  the contemplated change of circumstances rule by not only determining whether 
  the parties contemplated the change but whether the decree actually reflects 
  the expectation of the future occurrence).
II.Â Â Â Â Â  Offset 
Wife also contends the trial court erred in setting off the amount of Husbandâ€™s 
  retirement arrearage by the amount he overpaid in child support.Â  We disagree.
The evidence at trial demonstrated Husband had no control over the monthly 
  withholdings from his military pay.Â  Notwithstanding the automatic nature of 
  the monthly deductions from Husbandâ€™s pay, Wife contends she had the right to 
  assume the payments were voluntary monthly gifts from her former spouse. Â The 
  trial court heard both Husband and Wife on this issue and determined the payments 
  were not voluntarily made by Husband and were not intended or received as a 
  gift.Â  We perceive no basis for questioning this assessment.Â  Pountain v. 
  Pountain, 332 S.C. 130, 135, 503 S.E.2d 757, 759-60 (Ct. App. 1998) (â€œBecause 
  this court is not afforded the opportunity for direct observation of the witnesses, 
  we must accord great deference to the trial courtâ€™s findings where matters of 
  credibility are involved.â€).Â  Indeed, considering Husband had no control over 
  the payments, the family court acted well within its equitable power in crediting 
  those involuntary payments toward the amount of retirement benefits owed Wife.Â  

CONCLUSION 
Wife is entitled to an amount equal to 15 percent of Husbandâ€™s entire retirement 
  pay to be offset by the amount he overpaid in child support.
AFFIRMED IN PART AND REVERSED IN PART.
HEARN, C.J., and CURETON, A.J., concur.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
  In The Court of Appeals

 
   
     
      
        Clear Channel Outdoor, f/k/a Eller Media, Respondent,
      
    
  

v.
 
   
     
      
        The City of Myrtle Beach, and The City of Myrtle Beach Board of Zoning 
          Appeals, Appellants.
      
    
  


Appeal From Horry County
  Â John L. Breeden, Jr., Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 3849
  Heard May 13, 2004 â€“ July 19, 2004

REVERSED 

 
   
     
      
        Frances I. Cantwell and William B. Regan, both of Charleston, for Appellants.
        Douglas M. Zayicek and Howell V. Bellamy, Jr., both of Myrtle Beach, 
          for Respondent.
      
    
  

BEATTY, J.:Â  Myrtle Beachappeals from a 
  circuit court order reversing a billboard permit denial by the Myrtle Beach 
  Board of Zoning Appeals. Myrtle Beach asserts the circuit court improperly characterized 
  the Boardâ€™s scope of review and misapplied the cityâ€™s zoning ordinance.Â  We 
  reverse.
FACTS 
On July 6, 2001, a tornado struck Myrtle Beach, destroying a billboard owned 
  and operated by Respondent Clear Channel Outdoor.Â  The tornadoâ€™s winds fractured 
  the billboardâ€™s structural support beams in excess of their yield points and 
  caused the billboard to fall over and across an adjacent parking lot.Â  For reasons 
  of safety, Clear Channel removed the entire sign structure from the site, preserving 
  evidence of the damage by photographs.Â  When the City of Myrtle Beach (the â€œCityâ€) 
  studied the site to complete a storm damage assessment, the City discovered 
  that Clear Channelâ€™s billboard, which was previously thought to be a single 
  billboard, had actually been two separate billboards: one supported by 4 I-beams 
  and the other supported by 3 I-beams.Â  
After an initial inquiry with the Cityâ€™s zoning 
  staff regarding replacing the downed billboards with a single pole structure, 
  Clear Channelâ€™s real estate manager was advised that a permit to replace the 
  signs would not be issued because section 902.9.1 of Myrtle Beachâ€™s zoning ordinance 
  prohibited the construction of new billboards within the city.Â  On July 23, 
  2001, Clear Channel formally applied for a permit to replace the fallen billboards 
  with a new monopole structure.Â  By letter dated July 30, 2001, the Cityâ€™s zoning 
  administrator denied the permit on the same grounds that had been previously 
  stated.Â  
Following the zoning administratorâ€™s decision, 
  Clear Channel appealed to the Board of Zoning Appeals.Â  The Board found that 
  Clear Channelâ€™s closely spaced billboards did not conform to the requirement 
  in section 902.7.2.c.2 that a distance of 750 feet separate billboards.Â  The 
  Board concluded that section 902.8.3.d prohibited the re-establishment of the 
  nonconforming billboards because the damage was such that the structural supports 
  had fractured or exceeded their yield points. [1] Â  Additionally, the Board concluded that Clear Channel was not 
  proposing to restore the billboards, but to construct a completely new one, 
  and to issue such a permit would contravene the prohibition of new billboards 
  after February 10, 1998 in section 902.9.1 of the ordinance. 
On December 3, 2001, Clear Channel appealed to 
  the circuit court, which first upheld the Boardâ€™s decision, but then vacated 
  the first order and reversed the Boardâ€™s decision following a motion to reconsider 
  filed by Clear Channel.Â  The circuit courtâ€™s second order specifically found: 
  1) the order prepared by the City contained incorrect and unintended findings 
  and conclusions; 2) the City misconstrued and misapplied its ordinances; and 
  3) Clear Channel did not lose its rights based on an act of God.Â  This appeal 
  follows.
STANDARD OF REVIEW 
A zoning boardâ€™s findings of fact are final and conclusive on appeal and should 
  be treated in the same manner as a finding of fact by a jury and the court may 
  not take additional evidence. S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 6-29-840(A) (Supp. 2003). Appeal 
  to the circuit court is only for a determination of whether the boardâ€™s decision 
  is correct as a matter of law.Â  On appeal from the circuit court, the Zoning 
  Boardâ€™s decision should not be interfered with unless it is arbitrary or clearly 
  erroneous.Â  Heilker v. Zoning Bd. of Appeals, 346 S.C. 401, 406, 552 
  S.E.2d 42, 44 (Ct. App. 2001); Rest. Row Assocs. v. Horry County, 327 
  S.C. 383, 389, 489 S.E.2d 641, 644 (Ct. App. 1997).
